text.wiki:
The Museum aan de Stroom (MAS; Dutch for: Museum by the River) is a museum located along the river Scheldt in the Eilandje district of Antwerp, Belgium. It opened in May 2011 and is the largest museum in Antwerp.


== History ==
In 1998 the Antwerp city council decided to build the museum at the Hanzestedenplaats. On 14 September 2006 the first brick of the building was laid. In 2010 museum objects arrived from various other museums like the Ethnographic Museum and the Maritime Museum, which both ceased to exist. The museum opened for the public on 17 May 2011.


== Design ==

The 60-metre-high (200 ft) MAS was designed by Neutelings Riedijk Architects. The façade is made of Indian red sandstone and curved glass panel construction. It is an example of postmodern Art Deco architecture. The MAS houses 470,000 objects, most of which are kept in storage. The first visitor's gallery is the "visible store", which contains 180,000 items. The building is located on the spot where the Hanzehuis used to stand. International merchants worked and resided at the Hanzehuis. In the nineteenth century a fire destroyed the building.


== Collection and exhibitions ==
The central focus of the MAS is Antwerp and its connection to the world. The MAS collection ranges from maritime objects which document international trade and shipping, to the history, art and culture of the port city of Antwerp and to art and culture from Europe, Africa, America, Asia and Oceania. The MAS develops thematic exhibitions which connect local and global culture, art and history. The museum is committed to informing the public using new media and immersive presentations. The museum was internationally awarded for its MAS IN YOUNG HANDS initiative, which involves youngsters from very diverse backgrounds as event organizers and curators.


== References ==


== External links ==

text.quote: Striking red sandstone museum with high-tech exhibitions exploring Antwerp's place in the world.
google: The Mas is a great place to visit. We so many different floors have displays to different topics. The roof offers a great view over the city. We had to pay 10€ per person to enter, outside Corona its said that u can visit the top also for free. Happy days😊

nice view, many museum.
also have great cafe!
you can spend a day here

Really really nice! Just make sure to plan ahead well, if you want to see it all without rushing because it's a massive museum!

Museum contained some pretty good exhibits plus a terrace with views of the city. Current temporary exhibition about Japan is pretty good.
So many levels of fun! Price is great for what you get, the views alone are worth it.

One of my best experience in a museum.

Brilliant idea from the architect, very smart design. And amazing location too. Especially like those giant curved windows. They give a kind of vintage touch.
Beautyful building in the center of Antwerp, next to the docks with lot of levels to explore. At the top of the building you have a great view over the city center. A must see!
The view from the top of the museum is incredible, and you don’t need to pay to get up there (What I love the most)!! And there is very nice Exhibitions all the time!
This is one of the most fascinating museums I have been to in awhile. Each floor has its own exhibit and the views as you go up just keep getting better and better. Well worth the price of admission.
Nice museum with a Free rooftop terras. Great views on city, harbour and river Schelde. A must do in Antwerp!
Each floor with differing interest. Shipping section and pre Americas were both great. Top floor is free to access but the views are well worth the visit.

Fantastic bright ten storey building in the dockland area of Antwerp. Has to be visited - each floor has its own art exhibitions. These are chargeable but MAS is free. Escalators to each floor. Top tenth floor has a magnificent view all round of Antwerp and its port. A towering

A great museum and building with fantastic views at the top. There are a number of floors with some great information on Antwerp’s history and general world history too. Each floor has a quirky entrance. I definitely learned a lot and this was the most informative and

Since the opening in 2011 the MAS has become a fixture in the city. Although it took a while for Antwerpians to get used to the building's modern architecture they now can't even begin to imagine the city without it.The museum has played a vital role in the neighborhood' s

MAS is a fairly new museum. It has some interesting collections and has special exhibitions as well...one of which we were there to see. The building itself is striking. You take a series of escalators to get to the different galleries and all the way to the top floor (actually,

Our family enjoyed the MAS. We immediately bought a day pass and headed to the top floor. We took in the view of the city and was told we could see Brussels from our vantage point. We then worked our way down floor to floor viewing the exhibits. We found the themes to each
First time for us to visit the Museum after so many visits to Antwerp and must say we were very impressed .
You should start at the top of the building, great view over Antwerp and visit after that each level with different exhibitions.

MAS looks like a stack of shipping containers crossed with a warehouse. Its light and modern with great views at each level accessed by escalators but you need to be able to climb 2 flights of stairs for the panorama at the top. I Liked the use of modern photos side by side

This building is super-cool. Really interesting design with thousands of silver hand sculptures covering the outside. The route to the top takes you round a series of escalators with some interesting art and nice chill out areas with great views. The best bit though (I didn’t
Beautiful paintings and pieces, it is different than other museums that I visited. For English speaker, you have to scan a bar-code to know more about what are you looking at
great looking building lots of different things going on from school children work shops to exhibitions and the panoramic view of antwerp which is Worth the visit alone

This museum makes for a nice visit, you can select which floor(s) to roam and pay accordingly, in case you're in the mood for just a smaller portion of culture. The building is an attraction in its own right, and there were some nifty photographs on display in the public areas.

Just impressive in so many ways. This new museum is a knockout. Beautiful redstone building and inside is great with great tapestry of information to give you a great inside look at the history of Antwerp. Then a bonus is the top floor which gives you a great view of the city.
It is free to go to the top of the 10 levels to get the best view of the city and there are escalators up to last level. There is art on every level and a gift shop as you leave.
Good view from the top but most of the exhibition floors were either closed or not very interesting. I wouldn't bother again.

The MAS Museum in Antwerp is one of Antwerps more recently opened museums. It is big however one doesn;t need much time to visit it. The view on top is really worht the visit and your senses will be activated on your way up...

It has in total of ten floors. Artifacts from all over the world. I would suggest to take a complete day to see this place. As it's massive. And lots of interesting things to know n learn. It's so huge that one floor will never be crowded. Awesome to know world history.
Went there on a Monday and unfortunately they are not open on Mondays. Shame could not get to go the top as was looking forward to seeing Antwerp from the top
Very cool experience going to the roof. Wonderful view of Antwerp and its ports. Escalators and unique interior make for a neat experience.

The Architecture of this building is worth the visit. Plus, the view of Antwerp from the roof top IS TRULY over the top. Breathtaking views from the glass as you spiral up the building. Plus, a study hall in action for students. Take the enjoyable Walk to MAS. A must!

We spotted this off the toy train and went to visit. Can get a seniors ticket. lovely arty and modern but maybe just not what we expected. Maybe just showing the history and multicultural aspects of Antwerp. We had hoped for more paintings as they had large poster type

Fantastic place to visit and very reasonably priced. A great day out. Staff very helpful, even taking me up to the floor it starts on and all the way back down in a lift. Not to be missed on your visit. Incredible building and views
We spent several hours wandering around this place. Each floor has something different to view. Really loved the maritime floor. Lots of very different & interesting displays.
Very interesting place, although a museum, we visited just the viewing platform on top of the building. Had a good view 360 degrees view of Antwerp.
Nice structure in the middle of the old port. Inside you find a museum but you could go on the top of the palace for free. There you could find a very nice view of Antwerp
Worth going to the top to see the view. The architecture of the building is quite interesting as well. Very different.

A unique museum that caters for everybody, good varied exhibition that change on regular basis. We spend 2.5 hours in the museum and enjoyed every minute Museum is now in one of trendy areas with good restaurants around it
Visited this museum on a tour of Antwerp, colossal size and well worth a visit lots of visitors sitting around enjoying the view and the surrounding port..

This weird building is a must visit in Antwerp, you have the changing exhibitions on each floor, but you can also get free entry to the top floor an enjoy the view. Too bad that the highest floor is not accessible by an elevator for people with disabilities
Don’t miss a floor. So many great things about this to explore for people of all ages. There’s also spectacular view of the city.

You could spend hours in this museum.,or you you could climb 10 floors on an escalator to the roof to see a fabulous view of Antwerp. The view is free, open until midnight, everyday. We didn't have time to look round the museum, but we would definitely go back.
Always wanted to visit this museum. Fair price and all the way up is a great view over the city, the water, the marina. Amazing! Next time sunset!

We did not view any of the exhibits, though there were a few going on while we were there that I would have liked to have taken in but we were short for time. You can enter the building and go to the observation deck for free and get a spectacular view of a lovely city that is
We took our grandchildren to this museum and they loved seeing the ships and the view from the top. It was a cold rainy day but it was still enjoyable

Fantastic panoramic views but be prepared to go up what seems like a million escalators and last 2 flights stairs to get to level 10 for it. The glass has a cut out circle on each side perfect to take a picture through. And it’s free! I didn’t visit any of the art exhibits here

Definitely the one museum you have to visit in Antwerp. Every exposition was very different and the architecture (both inside and out) of the building is incredible. A new and unique take on a museum and very inexpensive (2.7 euros for students). There were interactive

We traveled by tram from the centre (helpful chap at Tourist Info in train station) and was pleased to get a teacher's discount (ITIC card) to get in - so do ask! The museum is lovely: well-designed with fab views and lots to take in on the way up. Wobbly stools and super views.

Free panoramic views from the top. Art displays are an optional extra and worth paying for. We were a family with kids and so chose just a few floors to explore as their interest was limited and certainly there was too much to take in. Sustainable Cities was very well done.

Museum Aan de Stroom (MAS) is based in beautiful building made of red bricks and curved glass. Walking your way up to the viewpoint on the 10th floor give a unique experience whereby the gorgeous city of Antwerp reveals itself slowly. There are plenty of interesting exhibitions

Great views from the platform at the top of this building on level 10. Some of the floors were closed to allow new exhibitions to be prepared but floors 5-9 were open. I particularly enjoyed the pre Columbian America with fantastic masks and pottery. Polynesian/ Papa New Guinea
Often special exhibitions in addition to the usual collection. The view from the roof top (access free) is worthwhile, if you don't have time to view some of the floors.

The MAS is not only a stunning building but 6/7 floors of different and changing exhibitions from the port history to 3rd world culture. We loved it as each floor brought new and interesting facts. However the best bit is the building itself especially the views from the top.

The view from the top floor is free. To see the museum collection cost a few euros. The collection is varied and two of the floors were closed. There are free lockers in the basement. It was raining when we got to the top floor, so did not go outside to find out what the
Nice building, nice surroundings. I can took picture from above. But when I was there, the 9th and 10th floor was closed. So I only can take pics from 8th floor

Nice collection of an historical ethnographical museum well worth the 5 euro price. I particularly appreciated the south american and sail/trade section. Only downside is that most of the text was in dutch although with in app it seems you could get some info as well. Some part

The building and the surrounding are absolutely stunning. You can use the escalators to go to the top of the building for free. The views are great and they change at every corner! The museum doesn't have a real collection apart from a small but beautiful Pre Colombian Art

We recommend starting at the top of this interesting building and working your way down as the views from the top are marvellous! The exhibitions, especially the one about the port, are fascinating and you should probably allow several hours to do it justice

MAS is a spectacular building in Antwerp. Not only its look but it is also worth to explore the exhibitions inside. I loved the fact that there were spots for students to study there, with tables facing the skyline of the city.
If u want to have an amazing view for free Than go to this place! A 360 panoramic view of antwerp. The museum is pretty awesome aswel!
Situated in a very pleasant area at the Bonaparte Willem docks. I only went to the top for Free for the view. €8 entrance otherwise I think. Other exhibitions you also had to pay for.

We did not visit the museum itself but used the elevators on the outside of the building to ascend the nine floors to the roof for a great view of the city. Love the architecture of the building itself as well.
Good for an hour to kill. Not a bad view from top. Free for a few areas and the scenic platform. Recommend.
We didn’t visit the museums on each floor but getting to the top is free. It was quite cold while we were there so the glass views really warmed us up! And the view from the top is really great 👍

We visited over the new year holidays and unfortunately we didn't see the museum proper due to holiday hours. However, the observation levels were open to us and they were well worth the visit. Great views.
As if the grounds and external architecture aren't enough to amaze you,the layout, displays and activities are awesome. I was completely thrilled.

The MAS offers a fantastic view all over Antwerp from the rooftop, which is accessible for free. I would recommend to visit this building once by day and once by night, as the illumination during the night gives a complete new impression and kind of "second" face to the facade.

A really interesting museum with a variety of different exhibitions that change throughout the year. Most museums in Antwerp are free on the last Wednesday of each month. There is a platform at the top which offers a great view of the port of Antwerp.
I went to see the moon trough a giant telescope!! This was a special night on the top of the museum! It was organized by the observatory of Hove (Antwerp). I enjoyed the city lights of Antwerp to!

This is a must-see on every Antwerp city trip. There is stunning architecture, a very interesting permanent exhibition, always good temporary exhibitions and one of the best city views. Visit of the viewing platform is for free. There are combi tickets with the nearby Red Star
You should visit MAS if you want to have a panoramic view on the city and both sides of the river. The entrance to the top is for free.

An impressive and imposing building...........but lacking in any exhibits that excite - or even interest. A curator who knows what their job is would dramatically improve the experience, and the building deserves it.
We saw this building from the waterfront when we went across the river. Quite a different architecture and an attraction for the tourists.

This is by one of the harbours and an interesting modern building just by itself. You can go up to the viewing platform without paying for the Museum, but they do have a variety of exhibitions which can be interesting.

The MAS (Museum at the River) is a recent addition to Antwerp's museum scene. It is an architectural beauty located in the old docks, but still xithin easy walking to the historic centre. At the top you can enjoy en excellent panorama. Every floor has its own topic from (old)

Visiting the MAS means exploring the building from the bottom to the top. As you make your way up, you discover that the museum is much greater than the building. The museum has a large collection, about 500,000 items, including artworks and utensils, which will tell you stories

This is a new beautiful museum. This you can't miss on your trip to Antwerp. Has free storage collections and Best view of City from it's 10 the floor. If you are interested in history of city inludings it's diamond trade and and it's ports , take a paid tour from 3rd to 8th

Due solely to lack of time I didn't visit the museum exhibitions themselves but at no charge one can ascend inside by flights of escalators to the roof of the building. From there through safety screens (with small apertures to allow clear photography) one can get breathtaking
Interesting concept combining a museum with interesting exhibitions with nice quotes of contemporary Belgian poets and a nice terrace from which you may enjoy the view over the whole city.

One of the most beautiful small museums, with a view deck on the top floor (that costs nothing) and a very interesting (paid) exploration of Antwerp's (maritime) history. If you're tired of portraits and Rubens and other Golden Age paintings which look all the same, this is the

Fantastic views (and the top level panorama view - open air; be prepared!) is free. Each level offers a great view from this very modern 8 floor museum with waving glass windows intended to simulate waves. Each floor offers a different kind of exhibit. One simulates museum

The MAS is not only an interesting museum with changing exhibitions, the building itself is worth a look. On the walls of the museum are tiny hands, the typical symbol of Antwerp. You can enter the museum for free, but you have to pay to see the exhibitions. A must do when

This part of Antwerp which has a lot of new development is very interesting. This building which is probably 10 floors gives an impressive view of the whole city. You can even access it with a pram or a stroller.

This is a unique experience, the building is amazing, the displays mind consuming, and interesting,somenot to everyone’s taste, but it is a modern art experience. Very educational and thought provoking

This is a museum , every floor something different, also sometimes temporary exhibition High building if you are on the top floor you can see the harbour and a view over Antwerp you can see how many churches there are To go to top is for free Downstairs you have souvenirs shop

The MAS building is in the middle of the old docks area with several adjacent bar/cafes. When we visited there were fascinating/crazy living art presentations on each floor and magnificent views from the top.

There's so much artwork to see here, it's highly impressive. Although there isn't so much room in here, theres a very large amount of things you can see. In matter of fact, while thinking back of my visit there I'm still perplexed at the large amount of works they have for

MAS did not impressed me in the first sight in terms of architecture. However, it turned out to be amazing when I got inside. At each floor, different exhibition themes can be found and all are interesting. Finally, when I reached top of the building, fantastic view of the city.
Good spot to spend time away from the hussle and bustle of the city. Good exhibits and excellent views of city.

We went to the museum to go and have a look at the views over Antwerp as this place was recommended to us by some local people and on the day we visited it was free. We had to put our belongings in lockers before we could go up the series of escalators but the views were

This museum is difficult to understand. It has 10 floors with wonderful views to whole city. But first couple of floors you really doesn't know what to think. It seems like chaos. Open your mind and after while the atmosphere will get you :)

When we arrived, we decided just to look around and not actually go into any exhibits, which cost money. We definitely did not regret our decision. The design was amazing and it's a good place for children. I highly recommend it to anyone who is anyone.

We walked to the MAS from the cathedral, about 20 minutes, and decided to climb to the top as it is free and the view over Antwerp is amazing. We did not look at the museum but I am sure it would be worth the entrance fee. The museum has escalators going right to the top so you

The tall building is beautifully designed and the view from the top on Antwerp is very nice. The materials seem to be sensitive to the times, who knows. The exhibitions are childish and mostly meaningless with explanations on cards next to it, very annoying.
Just go for the view from the roof. The kids will love the escalators to the top. Last Wednesdays of the month the entrance is free.

The museum is great and features all major artists; however after a whole week of modern art, added by Rembrandt, Von Gogh and Rubens, our best artistic moment of the day was sunset over the city of Antwerp and the beautiful shades provided by sunset under a clear sky with

The temporary exhibition "Dazling Desire" is about diamonds and their emotional desire. A splendid exhibition showing lots of jewelry with diamonds. Facinating! very well exposed. You need to takes the visitors guide (4 languages) to follow and understand the exhibition. Pitty

So sorry for waiting and expecting to see at least something interesting.. The only interesting thing,maybe,was the view of the town from the roof and the architect design of the building!even we visited all the exibitions in the other floors, hoping to change or improve our not

Nice museum on various subject. The focus however is on history of Antwerp and the harbor in specific. As such very interesting when you want to know about how Antwerp came to be. The other subjects are centered around the colonial history of Western Europe. That being said,

The building and architecture is amazing. Worth the 20 min walk from city centre. The exhibitions (10 euro) I didn't like too much but you can also go visit the building including rooftop view without buying a ticket.

We only went the 10 floors to see the amazing views of Antwerp and the harbor (second largest in Europe), but the museum looked amazing and wished we had the day to take this in. Don't miss the small visitor center about the harbor. It's amazing! A highlight of Antwerp, for sure!
Very nice museum. You can go to topfloor to enjoy the viewing of Antwerp. Visiting the viewing point is free.
This is a fun building to explore, you can go all the way to the top for some awesome views and visit various exhibits on the way.

Nice museum, but not only this is interesting. The building itself, the view on top and the location are worthwhile visiting! Lost of nice restaurants and pubs in the area, tou can spant quiet some time here.

nice exhibition centre. nice free rooftop views. just incredible for sunset. a bit tiring and boring to go all around the escalators to get up and down.

First, the obvious. This is a striking piece of architecture, particularly given that it is has no other tall buildings around it. And this innovation is carried on inside. It is in effect a collection of small museums with each floor focusing on a different exhibition. And many

It's really must see if you want to get a nice pictures of Antwerp. Entrance is free for panorama and basic facts about city itself. You can also pay for a ticket to museum's exhibitions. On the roof you will get a chance to snap great pics of Antwerp's port and downtown area.

When I visited there were no special exhibitions so I visited the standard exhibition which were O'K but not memorable. Having said that it was only 3 euros for me to get in so for the price it was fine. You can skip the exhibits and take the escalators to the top of the
We took the escalators to the top for free, just for the view. Took just 15 minutes. It was beautiful. Worth going even if you don't like art for the view.
Spent a few hours looking around here and also taking in the views as it is well situated to take in some great views of the city and the old port area.Worth a visit.
MAS is an amazing piece of art itself. There is a restaurant on top and a roof top that provide a panoramic view of Antwerp. Worth going!

We arrived a quarter to five, the museum floors close at 5. We just walked/rode up to the top floor on the escalators for a fantastic view ofAntwerp from this stunning building. An architectural marvel in red slate (?)

This museum gathers up several smaller ones from around Antwerp and houses them in one fabulous building. Take the escalators to the roof for free and gaze out over the north of Antwerp. The dock surrounding the museum has many cafes and bars. It is a vibrant and lively place,
We walked into the building not knowing if the observation deck was still open, but you have to take a few escalators to get to the top and there is no entrance fee.
You can walk for free to the rooftop where you have a wide view over the city. Impressive. There are some holes in the glass as well, which makes it easier to take decent pictures.
Not much to say. Great bulding Great view Very nice location Very nice city I suggest if you have time ti visit

We paid extra to see all of the exhibits. We were impressed with some exhibits such as the Paul and Dora Janssen-Arts collection but other exhibits were a little too avant-garde for our liking. The exhibits had enough to keep us busy and entertained & we are glad we paid the
The viewing platform is free of charge and offers amazing surround views of the AntwerpHarbour and trendy area around the docks. Also the exhibitions are well worth a visit. Great experience!
You can go to the rooftop of the museum for free and you'll have a nice view over the city of Antwerp and the river Scheldt

What a great piece of architecture and design. The MAS has free admission. There is only an entrance fee for the peranent and tempory exhibitions. The free admission also covers the Visable Storage area where you obtain a look at the storage facilities and the maintenance

The architecture of the building is amazing- first impressions were really good - even the outside area was well designed. I arrived at lunchtime on a sunny day so there were many people sitting outside having lunch in the large courtyard - plenty of sitting space on the large

My first time here and it was as I expected. The exhibits were pretty interesting and beautifully set up. The building itself is accessible - staff is very friendly towards special needs visitors - but the rooftop is only accessible through escalators.

Beautiful building next to the harbor. An area to visit you should not miss this place. It's a collection of art and there is many floors. It can be overwhelming but you can end the tour with a cocktail on the rooftop.

This building has an eyecatching design with it's waved windowsides. You can go inside and just go upstairs the escalators for the panoramic view above antwerpen. It's for free. If you are with a little one non-walker don't forget to bring your manduca (or so). They offer a
Wonderful museum, full of surprises. For all ages. Have a look at their website first and plan your visit as you won't be able to see all in one go..
Just went up to floor 8 with the elevator. The person in charge of the elevator saw us and offered (using walking wheels). Spectacular view from above and a monument from below. Highly recommended.

Located River) is perfectly perched located along the river Scheldt in the Eilandje Shopping district. It offers 10 levels of art experiences. Really enjoyed it all but was delighted with the specific Antwerp historical exhibits. For two adults it was 20 euros yet if you

Since it opened, I visited it several times: some times for a new interesting exhibition, some times just for a climb to the top to have a nice view on Antwerp at sundown, some times to have an excellent diner in Het Zilte, the Michelin star restaurant on top of the building.
Well done floor exhibitions with beautiful art pieces and great room designs. Cool building altogetheer.
There are various exhibitions in the 10 floors either for free or for money. However, going inside and enjoying the view is for free !

This museum is housed in a special building and some love it and others hate it. It's special and it gives you lots of opportunities to watch the city from above. The windows are quite impressive. They represent the waves of the river. The escalators bring you to the top of the
MAS offers a free visit to the top floor, where a panoramic view of Antwerp awaits you. Nice museum shop with plenty of real Antwerp gifts. Located in nice area full of restaurants and coffee shops.
Take you time when you are in Antwerp to climb the (mechanical) stairs. It will be worth it once you are on the top!
A must visit for both tourists and locals... Some Friday evenings the open the MAS for FREE and you can go right to the top and enjoy the stunning view of Antwerp from Night.

My favorite time to visit is at night, take the stairs up to the top floor and enjoy the beauty Antwerp has to give you! And...the view is free (all days, but closed on Monday). Make sure to check the calender to see which exhibition is showing.

Even though you're not interested in the exhibitions, you should definitely visit the rooftop. It offers an amazing view of the city and its port. Whilst taking the electric stairs, you can enjoy all kind of photos telling different stories of this wonderful city.
It's hard to believe that this building has been built in what use to be one of the old docks in Antwerp and it's a must visit for all people who enjoy living buildings.
We only went to the top floor, you have to pay for the rest! The view was great. Total panoramic of the city. Well worth a visit.
Worth to walk to this building and go to the top of it. Panoramic view is amazing and it doesn't cost anything.

Very cool museum. For two reasons. You can choose: first the art exhibition: very good. Surprising. Interesting. Absolutely worth visiting if you are interested in (modern) art. Second: the panorama terraces on the top level is for free and gives you a perfect few above the
I love the way this museum is set out. It is an experience in itself. The exhibits are varied and interesting and I certainly didn't get museum fatigue visiting this well thought out venue.

We were looking forward to seeing this museum and were impressed by the building and especially the view from the roof. The collections were so-so, a bit of a mismatch of different things from food to the port of Antwerp to Congolese masks to pre-Colombian art. But what put me
10 floors of museum in one building! Quite impressive and a lot of history of the city of Antwerp thru the centuries. At the 10th floor, you have a great view over the city and the Schelde!

The building draws your attention with its unique, modern architecture. It is free to enter and to have a walk up to the top with escalators. It is filled with art on every floor. The rooftop allows for a nice panoramic view of the city.

First off, I think you can go to the top without paying for the museum if all you want to do is see the view. Its not very clear though so you might want to check. The whole area is still developing and I couldn't help but think that in a few years the area will buzz with lots

This really is my favorite museum in the world, and I am not saying this because I am from Antwerp myself! The architecture of the building is amazing and the exhibition halls are cleverly build. Everytime you turn a corner, there is something else that catches your eye. My

We always do a Museum or two in countries we visit !! This one is a must do if you are in the Antwerp area !! 10 floors of different things, a great panoramic view of the city. And the special exhibits are always fun ! Reasonably priced !!

This museum has a few levels and each one givers you something marvellous to see. You will be able to see ships of a long time ago and ... Some levels gives you a differents times a new collection to see.
Coming to Antwerp and not going to the Museum aan de Stroom is a sin; don't be a sinner and don't forget this Museum aan de Stroom.
Very impressed with this museum. Interesting exhibitions and professionally curated. Treat yourself with more time spent there. Every floor has a different theme. Worth to visit!

Very special museum with nice views on the city , the port and river Schelde. On top a very good but expensive restaurant (2 star michelin) Around the museum you have "het eilandje" a place with a lot of restaurants and terraces to have a drink

You can go for free to the top of the MAS and you will get a great view of the city. Certainly worth a visit if you're in Antwerp. The museum is also interesting and they have regularly new exhibitions.
Very interesting : history of Antwerp. The buimding is incredible! There was a exposition of the famous Belgian painter Luc Tuymans who also created a sculpture on the square of a skull.

We did the walk / escalator to the viewing deck and one of the free exhibitions, however just wandering around this building is a treat. Interesting and stunning vista from the top and all levels. The architecture is sensational, the space is huge but you feel very
This is a very interesting museum conveniently located on the canal. It will take some time to visit all the museums but it is well worth the time. Highly recommended!

MAS is a very modern museum and manages to combine various topics with the city of Antwerp, which gives the exhibitions an interesting and local spin. It's modern nature means that it impresses with high-tech features: movies, sounds, and several ways for visitors to engage with

The view is the best part of this museum. Exhibits had no cohesion and really were nothing as described online while researching the place. If I were to plan my day in Antwerp over again is skip this place.

I love this museum! There are both permanent and temporary excibitions, so there is always something new to see in MAS! History of the town and port, trade and ships! There are pieces of art and history even on the escalators. And the view is amazing, stretching all over

Firstly, we did not have to pay to enter the building, not sure why. It is well worth the experience, the views from every floor are breathtaking and the building has been beautifully constructed and decorated. There are escalators on every floor so people who are unable to

A very interesting museum overall. it covers original topics (both permanent and termporary exhibitions), has an original architecture and offers an amazing view of the city of Antwerp (360° panorama) at the top!

10 stored building with panoramic view to the city. this museum is my one of the favorites and I like to go there from time to time. each floor is something different and tell u very different story. especially if like that before the exposition there is a room, which tone you

MAS is absolutely a museum to visit when in Antwerp. It is a modern building and inside you have a sense of space. The collection is well presented and you'll never get crunched in crowds... Sometimes (frequently) there are special exhibitions. A must see, for everyone
We went into museum and it was modern fun so inspiring and so much culture and art everywhere it was great
We visited this museum with a group of friends. It was a very varied group. The guide understood very wel that she had to adapt her text to several different kind of visitors.
The view from the roof is exceptional. It's free too. It's a long ride up by escalator and it's a fair walk from the town centre but it's a great view back into the town.

Nice museum with permanent and changing exhibitions. You can have a view into the museum's stock. Some exhibitions are always for free. The view from the roof terrace is spectacular. Restaurant is clos d on weekends (sic) but there are a lot opts for drink and food around.

Best thing of this all is the panorama on top of the MAS is absolutely free, that's what we've done to enjoy the view. It's one of the highest points in whole Antwerp and you can really see the whole city, from the "schelde" to the cathedral of Antwerp. Must go if you'd ask me!
it's unique building stands near the harbor holding from treasures what you can't imagine . if you are visiting anwerp then you must go there

My two daughters and I visited the museum today - the tickets cost me 10 euros, the girls (11 and 3) were free. The exhibits were on each floor starting with the 3rd. To tell the truth, I wasn't greatly impressed with them, some were simply shocking to see...I guess my favorite
Free access to the roof to take great pictures of the city. Worth going if you are visiting Antwerp!

Skipped museum and walked to the terrace (by escalator)! which was free for public to enjoy the whole 360º view of the city.....just amazing....its must visit place. Surrounding was also very nice to spend some good time.

Sited in the old port, this is a striking building with sandstone facings and interesting curved glass windows. Seen close up, the sandstone is decorated with metal representations of the Antwerp emblem. Alongside is a slightly academic gift shop, stocked mainly with books.

It is a place you must visit when you stay in Antwerp. A lot of culture and because it is so large always a quiet place to stay. You can walk on your own or guided. Don't forget the panoramic terrace, it is worth to go upstairs.

We only visited here for about an hour. we climbed to the top to see a beautiful view of Antwerp and the river. Would have like to see the whole place but our time was limited. Plan on spending a good part of a day there if you do go. The chocolate exhibit was small and a
We did not enter the museum, we only went to see the view from the top of the building and was well worth the trip plus it was free I would recommend it if you have the time to view the city

Spectacular building, great panoramic view of Antwerp from the rooftop. Access to the building (including rooftop) and part of the museum is free, but there is an entrance fee for the major part of the exhibition. I'm not entirely convinced by the exhibition concept. It's that

Everything about this building is pleasing; it's position, design and layout are outstanding. Every floor has appeal, from the study area to the free access exhibits. The panoramic view of Antwerp is wonderful; don't forget to look down at the skull mosaic from Luc Tuymans.

It all starts with the sight of the very special even futuristic design of the building. An eye catcher are certainly the large corrugated glass windows. In the museum you can, for free, the 7 (I think) escalators to go the the panorama deck and have a magnificent 360° view over
I went just for the panoramic view at the top and it was very worth it. You can clearly see the mix of old and new and have a notion of how large the port is.

When I firstly arrived to Antwerp, MAS were the first choice. Museum on every floor, great terrace to see the surroundings, restaurant and a cafe to rest and eat. This was the best way for me to start a new chapter! Bravo, MAS!
This is a bot out of the way, but it is worth it. Free panoramic view form the rooftop, and some exhibitions also free. Also great surrounding area to visit.
Beautiful view on the top of the building. Entrance for the panorama view is free. You can Also visit the place in the evening. There is Also a restaurant in the top of the building

One cannot miss the view of this remarkable Museum near the water and go on the roof to get the best views of the city . Antwerp has a lot of beautiful old buildings but also has a gem of modern architecture

Normally you go to a museum to watch what is inside, right? Try this museum when you are in Antwerp. This museum can amaze you with what is inside, but also the building itself and the location of the building has such a lot of beauty. Don't miss it when you visit Antwerp.....

A stunning new building with panoramic views of Antwerp (but inly if you are able to climb the stairs to the roof) and fantastic exhibition spaces. You have to pay to visit the exhibitions but there is free and fascinating access to one of the museum's storage spaces where they

The design of the building is interesting and the story behind it as well - there are hands planted on the outside of the building, and this is related to a legend of Antwerp, which I won't spoil for you now. I went to the top of the building (going to the top was free) and

The profile this building commands on the old dockside is striking, and the construction of the building will live with me for a long time. It's a massive place, and lead us to a brand new part of the city, which otherwise we may not have visited. There was a lot to see, and

View from the town from the top, however to be honest there isn't anything that impressive to see. The inside museum could be interesting however most details are not available in English so could catch the all meaning of all. There is one part which refer to the old time port

Walking along the river, the orange MAS stands like an icon among the cafes, boats and port of Antwerp. It's worth visiting for the 360 degree panoramic view of Antwerp. The architecture is innovative, green and enhances the port. Inside are exhibitions which focus on the
Well worth a visit as a historical review of this ancient seaport. The staff were excellent for there assistance and literature.
There are not too many tourist visiting the museum. It is about 15 mins from the grote markt and believe me you will enjoy it. The maritime history is very rich.
Unfortunately I didn't manage to see the exhibitions, just walked up to the viewing platform, which gives great views of the city. Views from each floor are also very nice.

No ticket needed to enjoy a great view of Antwerp! You can easily take the escalator to the 9th floor with only one flight of stairs to the 10th floor observation deck. We honestly didn't go in to the museum areas because we were limited on time, but it was worth just enjoying

The building is beautiful, or kind of, anyway. The "hand" -the trademark of Antwerp is dotted around ond the surface of this building. You can get to the top for free which is a great view. Beside the building is a nice area too.

What a shame that such a great building gets such poor curating. Although the names of the different exhibits were very tempting & promising none of them managed to please the eye or satisfy the curiosity. Many of the rooms were overloaded with objects but not enough light to

I went to this museum for the view from the rooftop, but was glad I took time to see the museum. Each floor has a theme based display of art, culture or history. The most interesting portion if the open storage which you can see. Most museums keep their storage vaults closed,

For sure one of the most amazing views in antwerp , made a visit in december they had the like an exhibition about the old islamic civilization , and they had the old key of the KAABA where muslims go to hajj , again i repeat its a go to photographers on sun set .
Unfortunately I was on the rush and couldn't see the museum, but I hear it's really nice. Gave it 5 stars for the panoramic view of the city which is free.
This was such a surprise and delight. Our boat was docked within walking distance of this museum. That was a real surprise and loved the rooftop view.

MAS is a fabulous building and suprisely good to do with kids; several search tours and they liked it a lot! The guards happy to help with searching things from the tours. We went to the café on first floor, nice space and good (but expensive as always at musea) Food. Nit that
You are able to go to the rooftop for free and it really is worth it. The view of the city is really beautiful. The building itself is also lovely and worth the trip just to look at it.

Each floor brings it's cultural interest and the top floor / roof top offers you the panoramic view of Antwerp. Really easily accessible, the stairs and escalators are really convenient to go up the floors. Brasserie is handy. Worth visiting!
Completely worth a visit. Nice view, and friendly staff there helps, and explained what exhibition there was.
Did not visit the museum. But the views from the top are free and well worth a visit especially on a clear day.
From the top of this building, the views across town are WONDERFUL. It's a great place to see the dock area and river plus all the taller sites in the town centre. AND IT'S FREE
there are many exhibitions on display to see its not an average bland museum. theres something for everybodys taste.

Entry to the building is free of charge, so no excuse not to go. You can go to the top of the building and have a look at Antwerp. The museum and temporary expositions are not free, you'll need to buy a ticket. Close by you have a small harbor and lot's of restaurants so please
There is no charge if you only want to see the fantastic view. You have to ride many escalators, yes many before you are up. You get 360 surrounded view.

A view from the top will leave you speechless, it's not too high offering amazing viewers of a beautiful Antwerpen. The museum collection I personally have found less interesting, but might be a good option on a rainy day.

I'm not a museum type of person but my hotel suggested visit for a nice view from the rooftop terrace. Make sure you dont buy a tciket as its free to visit the terrace but thats not imediatley obviousl when you enter the building!

Great view of Antwerp, city, river, ports...from this impressive building. Open to visitors for long hours. Different perspectives from each floor, and complete panorama from the top. Highly recommended.
Just worth going to the viewing platform if nothing else. The artistic value of the build in itself is amazing with the curved glass walls. Great view over the city. Free to go up.

My first visit of the MAS. Great and gorgeous building, but very bizarre, un-coherent exhibitions. As well, for the English native speaker: practically no translations. Very odd. The views are spectacular.

You can see the view of the city from day and night. It is a must see of the city. There is no doubt for me to say that you have to go there when you pass by Antwerp, not for the exhibitions but more to see the roof top !

Very interesting museum about the relationship between Antwerp and the world (city, river, port...). Impressive architecture. If on a tight schedule, at least climb to the terrace (free entrance) for breathtaking views over the city !

This museum has a number of small temporary exhibits. There was lots to see and I really enjoyed many of the exhibits. They covered a variety of interesting topics and information was available in English, as well as Dutch, French, and German. The entry ticket is only 3 euro for

We didn't visit any of the museum attractions but went up to the viewing gallery via the escalators, I really liked the pictures that are the backdrops to the escalators which are of local businesses both old and new-some of the pictures are quirky to say the least. Up on the
Went to see the views which were very nice especially since they were free. It was escalators up then steps to the roof so not sure how someone in a wheel chair would manage

The Museum aan de Stroom is a museum located along the river Scheldt in the Eilandje district of Antwerp, Belgium. The façade is made of Indian red sandstone and curved glass panel construction. Included in the Antwerp half day city tour, this landmark is not to be missed,

MAS is an abbreviation of the Flemish -Museum aan de Stroom - Museum by the river. The Museum was opened relatively recently - in 2011. MAS is the example of post-modern Art-Deco architecture. It attracts by interesting combination of Indian red sandstone and curved glass
A fantastic museum which gives the history of Antwerp from the old times till today. The panoramic view from the rooftop is spectacular. The last one can visit without paying an entrance fee.

I definitely recommend this museum for its architecture, location in the harbour and view from the top terrasse over the city... on top the exhibition are diverse and can satisfy adults and kids with 6 different themes at least covering antwetp its harbour or temporary
Great architecture, great views, and great exhibitions that rotate. Certainly worth a visit if you're in Antwerp.

Not to be missed sight in Antwerp. High modernist landmark building rising from the old dock area. Watch the created outdoor skull motif emerge on the ground below as you ascend the escalator - referencing the Quentin Massys memorial on the front of the cathedral. Fabulous view

Beautiful building with probably the best free view over the city. The permanent exhibitions are a good introduction to the history and culture of the city and Belgium. They also have temporary interesting exhibitions. The museum is huge, so if you wanna see the whole thing,

Amazing building with great city views from the roof. The exhibitions themselves are okay. Many explanation texts are only in Dutch (you can read the English versions if you scan QR codes with your smartphone).

A beautiful museum to walk around. The building itself is spectacular and the exhibitions are very interesting. They did a great job in making this museum attractive. Definitely a must go while you're in Antwerp!

Wonderful building situated on the quayside. I recommend exploring the building which you can do for free. The museum ,which you pay for, is lacking purpose and soul. It is as if they bought the building then thought 'what shall we do with it?' It housed the cities ethnographic
This is not just a museum with a solid collection and exhibitions, the building is also interesting from an architectural point of view. Do not miss the restaurant on the top floor.
MAS Museum is another landmark of Antwerp. It offers a beautiful and picturesque birds eye view of the city and the surroundings from the top.

We were really shocked by the photos on the walls (dead pig and cow heads - very bizarre- maybe they will add pictures of rotting corpses for our entertainment?) The curator of this museum needs to move out of the middle ages and into the 21st century. We were bored overall. The

Built in a very special way, great exhibitions, view from the top in brilliant! Must see when visiting my town!
It was a good place to spend some time, I am not a museum goer but i definitely enjoyed my time over there. View from the top was good and also i recollect there were some cool stuff inside

The MAS is one of the most iconic buildings in Antweerp. Its in a really nice sector of the city where you a ton of nice restaurants, galleries, art workshops, other museums and partying places. The Museum host itinerant expositions, normally more cultural than artistic. Some

Wonderfully diverse exhibits. Curiously, some floors had descriptions in English and others did not. We could not discern any theme tying the various floors together, but we thoroughly enjoyed the museum. We found we could have spent much more time there had we not had a

The MAS is my favorite museum in the world, and I've been to lots of museums in my life. It just has so much going for it. The exhibits are good (and include "interactive" ones where you smell and touch items), but the architecture is what really makes it. The escalators and
lovely building with an lovely ( cash only) cafe called storm in and great for gluten free - we went twice at lunch - fantastic view from the top
