Although I'm not a particular fan of Rubens, I completely enjoyed my trip to his beautiful home for three (3) reasons. First, his collection of art interested me more than his own work. Second, I learned a bit about how (upscale) people lived at that time - from the short bed
Visit this museum if you are very interested in Rubens. A good insight of the artist and his life and times. Nice garden too.

It was great to be in Rubens' family home. Great range of seventeenth century paintings and other artefacts. There is some building work going on so the garden isn't to quiet . My second visit to the Rubenshuis and will return again in my next visit to Antwerp.

I enjoyed visit to the Rubens house museum very much. Though it looks small from the outside, inside it's huge, many rooms with nice exhibits and a large studio too. Lots of Rubens' pictures and I really liked the garden too. A must see when in Antwerp.
We had a lovely visit to this fantastic building 3 minutes walk from the Elzenveld Hotel Superb building and equally matched by the stunning artworks

The home and garden of Rubens provides a window on the way the artist and his family lived. There were many alterations to the structure by subsequent owners, but the home was restored to its original configuration by using Rubens' own paintings for reference. A very nice
Rubens (the artist) lived in this place most of his life, and it houses much of his own private art collection. The garden space is quite elegant. There is good explanatory information throughout.

This is one of the premiere tourist attractions in Antwerp and it's certainly enjoyable, but is it Ruben's House? It's completely re-constructed and there's sadly little, except a few comments in passing, about Ruben and his family or about his workshop and professional life.

The exposition displays a combination of paintings, sculpture and furniture in that reminding of the concept of expositions Wilhelm von Bode had developed. Also, the exposition gives an overview of flaemish painting contemporaneous to Rubens, namely van Dyk, Brueghel and

Located near the Meir Street, this house is easy to locate. There is a small park with some sculpture and fountain near by. Entrance fees are paid at the modern office located in front of the house. There are lockers where visitors can temporarily leave their backpacks and

This is of course a must see when you are in Antwerp. A beautiful and impressive building showing the wealth of the famous painter Peter Paul Rubens who was born in Siegen, Germany in 1577. Rubens catered for the rich and famous of his time and part of their wealth spilled over

I thought I was going to learn about the man himself and see his art. In fact I learned and saw little. It was a nice house though, most of it reproduction (like the ornate wallpaper) but still impressive to see. It was worth the visit, maybe I just had my hopes up. Oh and the

Wow what a house! The building itself and the gardens already are spectacular, and so was the inside! Unfortunately, they don't actually have much art by Rubens himself (which they explain in their folder), but they do make up for this with other beautiful paintings and
Wonderful collection of Rubens' work in a well maintained setting. A little confusing to navigate from area to area. Not much explanation of the man himself, but still very worthwhile

This old house was the home of Rubens, and he did well in his time if you look around the house and garden. The ineterior itself is worth a visit, but you come here for Rubens right? Well there is a lot of of art, but not that much of Rubens, you will see a lot paintings of his
This house is well worth a visit. It was Ruben's home. Some wonderful paintings and a beautiful garden.
We went for the building. Stunning relic of old. Enjoyed the art while we were there too but it was secondary to the history of the building.

Absolutely worth the visit, mainly for the contents, but also for the building in itself. An absolute insight into the history and evolution of art at the end of the 16th century and into the 17th. Though I felt I learned more about van Dyck and Vermeer than Reubens that took
We visited here on a recent trip to Antwerp, I definitely recommend checking it out! It's absolutely stunning!
Beautiful old building, it was a shame that on the day we were there it was closed so we could not see inside.
With the work of Rubens and his colleagues you are taken back into time... all the rooms tell there own stories.. even the garden is beautiful.. I enjoyed every second of this visit

The former house of Antwerps famous painter Peter Pauwel Rubens. You can visit his house, his work place and the gardens. Located in the very center of Antwerp it's a must see for every visitor together with the Plantin and Moretus museum.

Came across this purely by chance whist we were walking around the town. It is a well preserved house, not just and are museum - there are of course several of Rubens paintings along with his most famous protégé - Anthony van Dyk (who became court painter to Charles 1 of

There are many beautiful paintings, not all by Rubens, furniture, statues, curiosities, good pieces of info in English, you climb the stairs in the house up to the top and back down then in to his large studio and finally a lovely large courtyard garden with some shade and

The Rubens' House is worth a visit if you have a spare hour or two in Antwerp. While not much of the building dates back to Rubens' time, it's architectural features and the paintings, mostly by Rubens' contemporaries, are of interest. They no longer offer the audio guide,
Very nice house/museum with several paints and not expensive (8 euro). Each paint has description in english too. It is located in downtown.
It is always a pleasure to visit the Rubenshuis. Every time it is possible to (re)discover some new particulars, it is nice, well maintained.
Nice museum and I recommend the audiotour. Surpricing few paintings of the master himself. It gives a good overview of the period, and Rubens life and some of his own artcollection.

Peter Paul Rubens lived in this house from 1610 to 1640. The house, furnishings and gardens have been lovingly crafted to produce as close to a seventeenth century artists's home as possible. Works by Rubens and his teachers and students are displayed as well as everyday

I'm glad we came here. I wish there had been more information about the home itself and it's architecture, but I know it's the paintings themselves which draw so many crowds. We easily spent a couple of hours here. I didn't know the home covered such a large area, and the
Peter Paul Ruben's was a master painter and very successful during his lifetime. He hired the best craftsmen and the best materials to build this home and garden. Every detail is seen to.
Visited with 2 small children: helpfull staff, no long queues, safe and very cosy. A hidden yard in the middle of the city! Ideal for the children to release some build up energy!
I love this house, it's pretty, surprising slough the way, very peaceful. Collection of paintings exposed is not the top, but still it's worth a visit.

The Rubens House was a very rewarding experience. The art of Rubens is both immense and breathtaking. You really appreciate the genius of Rubens by gazing at his beautiful masterpieces. Also, the house also has a lovely garden. Well worth the visit if you have any appreciation

What a fantastic museum to wander around at your own pace. Lots of interesting rooms to look at and the paintings by Rubens and other artists of his time were just fabulous! The staff were very friendly both at the booking office and inside the museum. At the booking office
This was a real treat!! The home is lovely, treasures incredible, guidebook and staff extremely helpful and we enjoyed a lovely Sunday morning in Reuben's home!! Thank you!

Visited the museum several times, the last time with my Spanish visitors. Everybody I've taken here has been absolutely mesmerised by the amazing art which is displayed here as well as the state in which the house itself is preserved. In my humble opinion a must-see for any

Rubens house and garden is a real joy to visit. And above all since June 27th 2017 David Bowie's Tintoretto can be seen there. David Bowie own the painting over 30 years. Some real great art of Rubens and van Dyck and Breughel can be seen at the museum too.
A wonderful museum. The interior takes you back in time. Many beautiful paintings by the master and other artists of the period. There is also a garden and café. Allow 1 to 2 hours for a visit.

If you like art and you like Rubens, this is the place to come. Great collection including some of the artist's greatest masterpieces. Non-art enthusiasts should also come here for some interesting education from the enthusiastic curators.
Rubenns house takes you back in time, it is a wonderfull example of the time, the interior is fantastic. And then the paintings, good for any woman's self esteem.

Think of this as a two-fer: an art gallery and a chance to tour the home of a master artist. The home itself is stunning, as are the gardens, and the free booklet, along with signage, does an excellent job of explaining what it is you're looking at.

First saw some of Rubens paintings in the cathedral and this inspired us to visit his house. A great visit, with a lot of information and paintings! Was very excited because the painting once owned by David Bowie is now there after being returned. Would definitely recommend a
Must see for art lover , huge collection in one place. gives detailed insight about culture and history. totally different luxury compared to Asia.

We visited on Sunday 9th July and were impressed by the house and the information given about the exhibits. The only minus for us, was we did not find any Rubens pictures of large ladies for which he has a reputation.

Nicely preserved house of the famous painter. Some of his works are here on display, but it is not a gallery per se. A painting by Tintoretto, previous owned by David Bowie, has been loaned to the house and hangs on the wall.

Rubenshuis as the name suggests is the actual house Peter Rubens liked in during his life. As if it wasn't enough just to visit the house of this great Flemish master, the museum contains many works of art by Rubens himself, plus works by other Flemish masters such as Van Dyck.

Very reasonable ticket prices. The house is wonderful full of old masters, particularly Reuben's of course. The decor and furnishings are from this period. The building facade is impressive as is the gardens. It also has a recently discovered Rubens on display that featured on

Differently from the Rembrandt house in Amsterdam, this little museum is really interesting and genuine. The master works of the Artist have been scattered all over the best museums of the world. There is almost nothing from him in the house, but there is a lot left from his own
Really interesting house with some amazing paintings by Rubens, Van Dyke and Breugel. Well worth a visit. The garden at the back is okay but not amazing. However, the paintings are fab.

This museum is a must see. We loved this house which was inviting and interesting. The Courtyard garden is also beautiful....well worth a visit. The entry allows you to visit all day and leave to have lunch/coffee......such an interesting and beautiful home.

One of the banes of group travel is being hurried along. Forty minutes here was but a mad dash. We were given an excellent little brochure that gave background on some forty pieces. The grounds of the house are worth looking at, especially the courtyard area and architectural
We loved the house and the good audio system which gave us a good explenation about his life. Antwerp is Well-worth to visit.

A very interesting museum depicting the life and times of Rubens. Lots of art and period furniture. The pace of the exhibit was very nice as were the gardens. If Rubens is of interest to you, then so will be this museum.

We expected to see more of Ruben's work here. The house itself is interesting to explore. Lots of period furnishings with mostly good signage. As a oldish house, it's worth seeing, but it wasn't worth the price.
I expected a tourist trap but found it a fascinating collection of old masters with superb notes in a printed booklet. Great gardens with monumental loggia and entrance arch. Stunning.

Located a few blocks from the main square, a pleasant walk. Tickets purchased onsite. Self tour of the home which is bigger than initial impression. Appreciation of the period but also valuable artwork by Reuben and VanEck displayed with explanations. Beautiful garden and
Nice small museum with a garden behind. Some very famous pictures from Rubens and the like. Observe opening hours. Tickets can be obtained opposite the house.
We went to Ruben's House only to find it closed. That was unfortunate due to the fact we were only in Antwerp for one. We did manage to see Ruben's paintings at the Cathedral of Our Lady.

I went there with my daughters (11 and 3), the ticket was 8 euros, both girls were free which was great. It is a short walk from a central train station, about 15 minutes, not too far at all. We all were impressed by the house, lots of little details,the painter was clearly

Well laid out displays of Rubens and his associates. It was interesting to learn the details of the house and its restoration. Although the rooms were small, there was never a sense of being crowded or being pressured to "move along."

Wished our schedule had allowed more time in this wonderful historical house. Fascinating and well worth take time in your trip to see it properly. Truly wonderful art and wall dressed with Spanish leather
No starving artist here. The size of the home, gardens was astounding, along with all the paintings of his and his contemporaries. I specifically stopped in Antwerp for this experience.
This an original house where Rubens lived and died. Interesting furniture and artifacts from that era.

This was well worth the 8 Euros. Some fantastic insight to the man's wealth, and some really wonderful art from a number of artists. Some of the still life works were truely remarkable. Relax in the well maintained gardens afterwards.

Its a nice cozy royal feeling house of Famous painter Ruben. Ticket is little much overpriced but interior is awesome like Gold plated leather covering on walls, I saw it first time. It has some nice paintings and wooden craft work too. Its must visit for Antwerp travelers

Visiting a Rock Star's house can tell you a lot about the person. So this is the case with the Rubens House. It offers you real insights into the person...his style, likes and dislikes. Worth the visit.

Having spent well over an hour touring the property I feel that Rubens was an incredibly well connected artist, to have afforded such a grand property. It was magnificent! It was worth downloading the free app that you can use, but remember to take your headphones, otherwise

This museum was recommended to us. It's fabulous! Located in the heart of the shopping/dining district of Antwerp, it is exceptional. Rubens' home is gorgeous and it's got a great collection of art and furnishings in an intimate setting. I learned a great deal about the

Antwerp has done a splendid job in preserving this magnificent mansion, the home of their famous and favourite son, P P Rubens. The place illustrates how successful and wealthy Rubens became during his lifetime. Together with the Cathedral, an absolute must to visit.

After a few disappointments with artist's houses elsewhere, which were mostly modern recreations or clumsily assembled models, this was a gem. Atmosphere is somewhat gloomy, you will feel immersed in the past. Most paintings are not by Rubens, but selection is clever and tells a

Nice little house of Paul Ruben now converted to museum. It's cramped inside so you have to have patience and this is definitely how handicap accessible but it is his original home. Lots of stairs too. The art is lovely though. Worth the walk through.

When walking from the central railway station towards the historical city, just Jump to the let hand side from the Meir and after 200 meters you will find it. It is Big house of Peter Paul Rubens. His life and art in one.

Many rooms containing paintings, furniture, statues and other artworks. I am not personally a fan or art museums, however I found this enjoyable - surprise! The building itself is lovely and has an outdoor garden for a short stroll. The architecture outside in the rear is

OK, you are in Antwerp, home of Peter Paul Rubens.....so you gotta see his home. You get a feel for how wealthy he must have been, and a feel for the art of the period. The art is good, and there is enough variety to keep even the non-art lover entertained. Look for the chair

A beautiful, well-decorated museum in a well-preserved historical building. The place has an impressive, beautiful collection of art-work and paintings. It gives a good and complete overview of this artist's life and the art work he collected from other contemporary artists. Not
Nothing really on Rubens life style or the house furnishing. Good collection of "loaned" pictures including a lot on Van Dyke. Nice garden but 50c for the loo!
One gets the feeling of moving back in time to the dwelling of a very wealthy artist. Remarkable that Rubens was rewarded during his lifetime. Fine paintings, a pleasant, modest-sized museum.

A must see in Antwerp is Rubenshuis. It's easy to find, just off the main shopping precinct, and you can wander at leisure through the house, gallery and gardens. As a retired art teacher I found it fascinating to have an intimate view of the life of Rubens, but the appeal is

The building and all the paintings were so impressing. Generally in the big museums I'd be stressed because I'd want to see everything I hang out so peacefully here because it's not a huge place and there are amazing paintings.. The garden is not much big but nice, spent some

Interesting visit with nice guidebook. Beautiful house and garden. The work exhibited are none if the major works but interesting nonetheless, and accompanying descriptions are carefully done. Well worth the visit.

The house is interesting but hard to navigate . The information in the guides is confusing. Also we had walked past the house several times before realising where it was. It needs to have more publicity .

Rubens is the greatest artist to be found in Belgium, making this a truly must see site. Not only does it give a new insight into the wonderful life that he must have lived, as evidenced by his home and the affluent social circles he enjoyed, which included a significant
A visit is worthy just to have the chance to see how the houses were furnished back in the Rubens's time. The guide provide exhaustive informations wich increase the interest of the visit.
Beautiful gallery and helpful curators. Clean restrooms. Also has an adjacent cafe which makes lovely coffee and outstanding light lunches. It's a place which I would revisit.

Beautiful place , a bit small, a bit expensive 8 euros for this tiny place , a beautiful garden, amazing peaces, as a big lover of Rubens I was a bit disappointed it wasn't enough for me, I wanted to see more from his work...

The entire setup was very authentic - it felt like traveling back in time. The lighting is good and some of the works of art are truly inspiring. I had a good time looking through the collection - even though I am not having any background in art or history. The staff are

If you wane get an insight on how houses looked several centuries ago, it's a great place to visit. Do not expect to find a big nor exclusive collection of painting, those are stored in another museums. It's a very know place to visit once you set the right expectations.
Lovely seeing where he used to live and the syle of the house, it was also nice to see the paintings bases in situe
nice and small museum, with really nice paintings. it gives a nice view how rubens had lived there. the explanation is given by a small textbookin different languages
Beautiful house and interesting audiotour. Good for a rainy or fair-weather day. Think of this as a beautiful museum.

the bouncers that were at the Rubens House entrance, i.e. the security folks, enjoyed not letting us in at 1630, the closing time, because they said that they are public officials and drop their pens at the exact time. They were very proud of their attitude and laughed. Seemed
What an amazing place Rubens created to live and paint in. While the paintings are the main attraction for many, the architecture of the house he bought and then added on to is wonderful.

Well known Rubens lived and painted here during some 25 years or more. Personally, I found not very easy to find in general the tourists' visiting places in the city. In the ticket office in front , there are also free lockers big enough to leave your jacket; very helpful for

The first port of call in our visiting calendar. Fascinating house, and beautiful paintings in the sort of settings they were designed for. Rubens was a successful and popular artist during his lifetime and his home and lifestyle reflect this. Soaked it all in and could easily

Rubens lived here for about the last 40 years of his life. It is evident that he was not a starving artist! If you enjoy art, architecture or history I think you'll like this museum. It is full of works from his personal art collection that are very beautiful. You also learn
Rubens lived here after he had 'made it' and was a rich man. Great interiors and original artworks, lovely courtyard garden behind the house

Rubens house gives you the chance to experience great art outside of the sterile atmosphere of most art gallery's. Being able to see the artists work and residence and also to read about his life all under one roof was a really engaging experience.
The house of Rubens is worth the visit if you are interested in art and art history. The house itself is amazing and there are several art pieces received by Rubens inside.

If you are planning to see the fabulous Rubens paintings in the cathedral , the many churches and Rockox house then Rubens ' own house is an essential part of your itinerary. As well as the great artefacts by Rubens and contemporaries it's a great way to get a feel for Rubens'

A visit of the Rubens House is certainly very interresting. You get a small guide at the beginning with information of all the rooms and important paintings. You get to learn a lot about Rubens life and what he meant in the 17th century. The museum gives a good impression on how
The museum is not too big so you can enjoy every singl piece of Peter Paul Rubens. Rubens house is beautiful baroque building with a nice calm garden.
One of my favorite museums in Antwerp. Totally immersed in Rubens' world the 17th century. I especially like the garden.
A very small museum, that reveals to be a little pearl, showing the intimate life of Rubens and his beautiful atelier. Very much worth visit.

On a sunny March Saturday, Antwerp is a busy place, full of shoppers and cafe goers, but tucked up a side street off the main shopping area is the lovely house that the artist Rubens lived in and is stuffed with fabulous art and furniture from the time. The entrance fee was
a small museum and garden area, just a few steps from Mier shopping area. Great pictures to see and compare for historical contexts.... very pleasant to see and walk through

Just close to the old centre, next to the main shopping street, there is the original house and workshop of this world famous painter, Peter Paul Rubens. Visit, get an idea how he lived - what a luxury! - and take a look at his workshop. Enjoy the paintings, sculptures, have a
It's a nice museum but the staff are very rude and unwelcoming. Don't expect to spend much time here, you can't go back to rooms and wander.

Despite the fact that the arches in the garden and the garden itself are in need of restoration, and that will happen in the near future, this house throws you back in time. Back to the days the grand master worked and lived here. The house and the excellent art works will give

We are not learned in art history but we are as impressed as anyone by the Banqueting House in London so we wanted to see something on a smaller scale by PPR. The experience was entrancing. It seems to be a part-Gothic, part-Mannerist building with a touch of realism. Apart
Nice size museum of Rubens house. Split in to different rooms to get a sense of what it was like when the artist lived and worked there

Visit the Rubenhouse and get immersed in the way the grandmaster lived and worked. The tour takes you through the old house, the atelier where he worked as well as the Gardens. You will enjoy the peace and tranquility of this place, while it being situated in the city center.
Rubens was a very rich painter and lived in his beautiful house from 1600 till 1640. He enlarged the house with a half round museum for his Roman statues.
This is a trip into the age of great artists. You can see how Paul Rubens was living and you can see a lot of other artist. Also the house an the garden are beautiful.

The three oldest printers in the world are here. Even the one in the Gutemberg museum in Mainz is not that old. The books from the Emperors, the protestants, the jews, the catholics, ancient maps, science, literature... the knowledge of an age stored in one of the few buildings

This is the house where Rubens lived, worked and taught (Van Dyke amongst others) and it's a wonderful p[lace to imagine his life and times. It's huge, quite stunning and full of artwork by all sorts of people, such as Breughel and Van Dyke, as well as you know who. Lots of

This very manageable museum provides a great peek into the life of Paul Rubens. Not only does one get a sense of his life but also his interactions with other artists of his time. Additionally, one can feel both the Belgian and Italian influences on him. It is a nice mix of

Great place to see in heart of Antwerpen. Lady guide was interesting and told us many great stories about Rubens and other famous painters from that period. Place that you should visit and take your guests to see.

Beautiful image of a long bygone era. Not only the most impressive works of the master but also the way how the Rubens family and their servants lived. Buy your tickets in the glass building in the middle of the square and enjoy your visit!

Exceptional restored building, interior not so original nor complete which ougt to be quite as it should be if you realise all what happened in Antwerp over all those ages and years of occupation by foreign invaders!

Situated in a lovely 17th century house, this museum exhibits Ruben's personal art collection, as well as many of his own works. You can see a lot of nice paintings and upon arrival you are given a guide with info about all the paintings

Beautiful garden portico, studio, garden pavilion designed by Rubens. Quaint kitchen with fireplace, blue and white Delft tiles, utensils etc Still life paintings by Antwerp's best 17th c. animal and still life painter Frans Synders who was a friend of R. Adriaen van Utrecht's
Really nice museum about the life of Rubens in Antwerp. Not only paintings but also other item from that period.

Absolutely to be visited. You feel the atmosphere from that period and you can imagine the painter's life with his family. Paintings are breathtaking and you can spend an entire day in admiring all the beauty.

Rubens is one of the greatest masters of his time. And he was successful...wealthy. This mansion he lived in is stunning and you get to travel through the rooms learning about his career, art history, different genres of flemish art at the time, and what it was like to live in
Its always interesting to see were the artist spend his time. Where did he sleep and eat. It's impressive.

Rubens House, where he lived and worked, and where his pupils worked for him too. Visit the museum (100's of his paintings) with a local guide to get the inside info and pleasant annecdotes. Why did he incorporate so many local figures into his paintings... It's all about the
It is a very good museum, although sometimes you wish to be able to get closer to the objects exhibited. Watch your step: there are strings and bells everywhere.

Antwerp has many historic attractions. The Rubens house is probably the best. It is the place where the famous painter lived with his family. Both interior and exterior breathe the 16th/17th century. There are many interesting paintings, including ones painted jointly by Rubens

Despite not being a great fan of paintings, I found this museum amazing, thanks to the way all paintings are explained nicely, and how they are scattered throughout the house of Rubens. The house itself is pretty magnificent and well worth a visit. The ticket price is also cheap

This is a really good place to visit if you are interested in art, which we are. We thoroughly enjoyed the house and thought it was a very interesting and moving experience. Worth going to if you are visiting Antwerp and want to do a bit of sight-seeing...
Great historic value. The history of Rubens explained. The building has been excellently renovated and is worth the visit just for that.

This is a beautiful home and garden right in the center of town. Rubens collected some great paintings and there are some of his own works there as well. He lived very well and the home has been beautifully restored..It takes about an hour to see..Don't miss.
Rubens was not only an artist but also a statesman and politician. His art can be found in museums around the world, his legacy can still be found in the fabric of the Europe we live in today...
When visiting Antwerp you should not forget the Rubens house. Conveniently located in the city centre it is very interesting visit which lets you understand the genius of this painter.
Exceeded expectations, not only the place gave an idea of society at the time, but it is also a great container of art masterpiece.
A great museum featuring a lot of Rubens paintings as well as other artists. To visit his house walking through rooms where he walked is an amazing experience.

If you like Rubens art then you will want to visit his home and see some of his person stuff plus other aspects of how he lived back then and how he was views by the locals and aristocrats. Interesting history inside this home and as you walk the courtyards outside. A must see

This wonderful place was designed by Rubens, done in Italian style. I adore the amazing gazebo he dedicated to his brainy brother, the sculptural portico, and the contemplative and marvellous garden with benches you can sit at. Even the stair finials are elaborate! The art is

A 'highlights' collection of approximately 50 pieces set in the backdrop of Rubens' house. The artwork had me captivated! The house makes a very favourable and enjoyable backdrop however in some instances the lighting/painting placement is not optimal. This should not put you
Fun to see the very well preserved home of a grand master. The structure and windows look like new and the building is clearly hundreds and years old.

The Rubens house is an absolute must in Antwerp! The architecture of the house and the garden are astonishing. The pieces of artworks are also very nice to see! You spend easily 90 minutes in the house!
I visited the museum and found it to be very interesting. Learned a great deal about Antwerpen history here and enjoyed some of the art work and personal collection of Rubens.

We really enjoyed exploring the house and grounds. The house isn't that big but is packed with art and history. We got the audio guide which was worth the few euros extra, though the little booklet you get with your ticket provided a useful, brief overview of the artwork on
Interesting place fundamental for the history of art. Rubens was one of the best artists in history and after a visit here you will know him way better. Come and make a visit.
If you come to Antwerp you must visit this museum. It's magnificent with all of the beautiful paintings. It's breathtaking.

Rubens House (as the name suggests) is the house of the famous artist Rubens. However, this is not simply a view of Rubens' artwork inside. Visitors can tour the house at leisure and are also provided with audio guides (for an extra charge). Nevertheless, the breadth and

It is a must to visit the Rubenshuis while your stay in Antwerp. The house of Rubens is well conserved and when you enter you feel like you need to be quiet and just enjoy all the beautiful paintings of him and also of Anthony van Dijck. Even our boy of 8 did like the visit.

We have been to Rembrant's House in Amsterdam and certainly knew Ruben's was more affluent, but had no idea to this extent. Most definitely worth the time if you are an art aficionado. Really enjoyed the trip there.

If you're visiting old Antwerp, I'd definitely recommend this as a "must see" item. The house is very interesting with plenty of original paintings. The real treat, however are the patios overlooking the garden. Rubens took much of his inspiration from classical Italian

The building where Rubens lived is really beautiful and well preserved. We enjoyed the tour, which is short enough that the kids could share the experience. They have paintings from Rubens and other painters from the same era. If you're in antwerp, I would highly recommend
Obviously one of the most well known painters of the European movement and a visit to the hose was lovely - gives you a sense of the wealth and status of the man at the time
This is the house where to painter Rubens lived and worked. The is a nice collection of his paintings.

The house itself is already quite impressive, certainly the façade on the courtyard. The museum houses part of the art collection that Rubens had, he was an art dealer as well as a painter and diplomat. It also houses some of the paintings that good friends of him had, which is

Ruben's house is a wonderful place mixing history, architecture and, of course, art. The paintings are stunning and the garden is lovely. Something that upset me, though, were the guards; wait, so, I'm not supposed to go back if I missed something? That was odd or maybe I
Come here with confidence. Pay your entrance and enjoy the setting, inside and outside in the garden! A jewel in Antwerp!

I have been there every decade or so since lived in Antwerp. It started as a very low key museum with a nice selection of Ruben's pictures in his house. Now, there is a ticket station, but still not overcrowded. Easy to get to off main street.

I really like the Rubens house. As the name tells you, this used to be the home of Pieter Paul Rubens, one of the best baroque painters that has ever existed. It gives a good insight of how the people used to live in those days. They kept the original decorations and furniture.

Not to be missed: Art and architecture of Reuben's. The art history lesson is perfect. The architecture was great to see. Sit a spell on the garden as well. Do the audio tour included with ticket price. I also got a discount for taking the train the same day as visit.

Any person who love art and history of art must see Rubens house. It is located just in the centre. The rooms and pictures and patio made you feel like you are in the 17th century all together. The brochure is included in the price tickets where you can find all the explanations

Interesting to realise that this artist was financially successful in his lifetime. Quite a collection of paintings on view, but surprisingly few by Rubens himself.

Various painting and very beautiful house. interesting. I appreciate the garden too. Not so long and could be better with more Rubens' painting but if you are in Antwerp.. go!

This museum is a must for visitors to Antwerp. From the gilt leather walls to the four poster bed, this place was captivating. So opulent!

Even not being an art lover...I enjoyed walking through the house, studio, and garden of this famous Flemish artist. I learned a lot and that is why I take the time to tour places like this!

Sorry, but nothing special for me here. If you are in Antwerpen and you are in central zone, go and look, just to know you were there.

A very well preserved interesting historical site in the middle of the Meir Street (one of Antwerp's main shopping areas).
Must see when visiting Antwerp. This tour will take about an hour. Located next to main shopping street.
It was a cute little museum but we didn't bring out passport so we were allow to get the audio set. Would of been nice to at least pays deposits. It's near the Meir and very easy to find

I really enjoyed my visit here. It has a lovely collection of artworks by Rubens and others and one is likely to find an artistic gem that connects with you. It is relatively inexpensive with a free small guide book as well as an other slightly bigger guide book for only €2

He is one of the most influential person in Antwerp. If you like to learn about history and Baroque, this is a place to come. Noted it is close on Monday

Excellent museum, wonderful surroundings in the heart of Antwerp a fantastic place to escape the hustle and bustle of this amazing city.

This was a very intersting and educational stop, a must do for art lovers, it shows you a large collection of Rubens paintings and art as well as illustrating the way he lived.

This is a medium to small museum that is interesting not only for the works of art on display, but for the history presented of its owner and, if you are a fan of seeing how people lived back when, the furniture and furnishings of the house itself.
A unique , no nonsense top location. You feel in touch with the master ! Esthetics, history, gothic, renaissance all united in harmony

I really really enjoyed my trip to Rubenshuis. Everything was well explained in the mini guide handed out at the ticket office and the building is glorious.
Well worth a visit - not just on a rainy day. Beautifully restored historic Rubenshouse in the middle of Antwerp. Not much of Rubens work, but a lot of his life time peers.
its ruben house the famous antwerp Painter and artist. its nice and historical in center of the city

text.wiki:
Antwerp ( (listen); Dutch: Antwerpen [ˈɑntʋɛrpə(n)] (listen); French: Anvers [ɑ̃vɛʁs] (listen)) is a city in Belgium and the capital of Antwerp province in the Flemish Region. With a population of 520,504, it is the most populous city proper in Belgium, and with a metropolitan population of around 1,200,000 people, it is the second largest metropolitan region after Brussels.Antwerp is on the River Scheldt, linked to the North Sea by the river's Westerschelde estuary. It is about 40 kilometres (25 mi) north of Brussels, and about 15 kilometres (9 mi) south of the Dutch border. The Port of Antwerp is one of the biggest in the world, ranking second in Europe and within the top 20 globally. The city is also known for its diamond industry and trade.
Both economically and culturally, Antwerp is and has long been an important city in the Low Countries, especially before and during the Spanish Fury (1576) and throughout and after the subsequent Dutch Revolt. Antwerp was also the place of the world's oldest stock exchange building, originally built in 1531 and re-built in 1872.The inhabitants of Antwerp are nicknamed Sinjoren (Dutch pronunciation: [sɪɲˈjoːrə(n)]), after the Spanish honorific señor or French seigneur, "lord", referring to the Spanish noblemen who ruled the city in the 17th century. The city hosted the 1920 Summer Olympics.


== History ==


=== Origin of the name ===

Early recorded versions of the name include Ando Verpia on Roman coins found in the city centre, Germanic Andhunerbo from around the time Austrasia became a separate kingdom (that is, about 567 CE), and (possibly originally Celtic) Andoverpis in Dado's Life of St. Eligius (Vita Eligii) from about 700 CE. The form Antverpia is New Latin.A Germanic (Frankish or Frisian) origin could contain prefix anda (“against”) and a noun derived from the verb werpen (“to throw”) and denote, for example: land thrown up at the riverbank; an alluvial deposit; a mound (like a terp) thrown up (as a defence) against (something or someone); or a wharf. If Andoverpis is Celtic in origin, it could mean "those who live on both banks".There is a folklore tradition that the name Antwerpen is from Dutch handwerpen ("hand-throwing"). A giant called Antigoon is said to have lived near the Scheldt river. He extracted a toll from passing boatmen, severed the hand of anyone who did not pay, and threw it in the river. Eventually the giant was killed by a young hero named Silvius Brabo, who cut off the giant's own hand and flung it into the river. This is unlikely to be the true origin, but it is celebrated by a statue (illustrated further below) in the city's main market square, the Grote Markt.


=== Pre-1500 ===
Historical Antwerp allegedly had its origins in a Gallo-Roman vicus. Excavations carried out in the oldest section near the Scheldt, 1952–1961 (ref. Princeton), produced pottery shards and fragments of glass from mid-2nd century to the end of the 3rd century. The earliest mention of Antwerp dates from the 4th century.
In the 4th century, Antwerp was first named, having been settled by the Germanic Franks.The Merovingian Antwerp was evangelized by Saint Amand in the 7th century. At the end of the 10th century, the Scheldt became the boundary of the Holy Roman Empire. Antwerp became a margraviate in 980, by the German emperor Otto II, a border province facing the County of Flanders.
In the 11th century, the best-known leader of the First Crusade (1096-1099), Godfrey of Bouillon,  was originally Margrave of Antwerp, from 1076 until his death in 1100, though he was later also Duke of Lower Lorraine (1087-1100) and Defender of the Holy Sepulchre (1099-1100). In the 12th century, Norbert of Xanten established a community of his Premonstratensian canons at St. Michael's Abbey at Caloes. Antwerp was also the headquarters of Edward III during his early negotiations with Jacob van Artevelde, and his son Lionel, the Duke of Clarence, was born there in 1338.


=== 16th century ===

After the silting-up of the Zwin and the consequent decline of Bruges, the city of Antwerp, then part of the Duchy of Brabant, grew in importance. At the end of the 15th century the foreign trading houses were transferred from Bruges to Antwerp, and the building assigned to the association of English merchants active in the city is specifically mentioned in 1510. Antwerp became the sugar capital of Europe, importing the raw commodity from Portuguese and Spanish plantations on both sides of the Atlantic, where it was grown by a mixture of free and forced labour, increasingly enslaved Africans as the century progressed. The city attracted Italian and German sugar refiners by 1550, and shipped their refined product to Germany, especially Cologne. Moneylenders and financiers developed a large business lending money all over Europe including the English government in 1544–1574. London bankers were too small to operate on that scale, and Antwerp had a highly efficient bourse that itself attracted rich bankers from around Europe. After the 1570s, the city's banking business declined: England ended its borrowing in Antwerp in 1574.Fernand Braudel states that Antwerp became "the centre of the entire international economy, something Bruges had never been even at its height." Antwerp was the richest city in Europe at this time. Antwerp's golden age is tightly linked to the "Age of Exploration". During the first half of the 16th century Antwerp grew to become the second-largest European city north of the Alps.  Many foreign merchants were resident in the city. Francesco Guicciardini, the Florentine envoy, stated that hundreds of ships would pass in a day, and 2,000 carts entered the city each week. Portuguese ships laden with pepper and cinnamon would unload their cargo. According to Luc-Normand Tellier "It is estimated that the port of Antwerp was earning the Spanish crown seven times more revenues than the Spanish colonization of the Americas".

Without a long-distance merchant fleet, and governed by an oligarchy of banker-aristocrats forbidden to engage in trade, the economy of Antwerp was foreigner-controlled, which made the city very cosmopolitan, with merchants and traders from Venetian Republic, Republic of Ragusa, Spain and Portugal.  Antwerp had a policy of toleration, which attracted a large crypto-Jewish community composed of migrants from Spain and Portugal.By 1504, the Portuguese had established Antwerp as one of their main shipping bases, bringing in spices from Asia and trading them for textiles and metal goods. The city's trade expanded to include cloth from England, Italy and Germany, wines from Germany, France and Spain, salt from France, and wheat from the Baltic. The city's skilled workers processed soap, fish, sugar, and especially cloth. Banks helped finance the trade, the merchants, and the manufacturers. The city was a cosmopolitan center; its bourse opened in 1531, "To the merchants of all nations." Antwerp experienced three booms during its golden age: the first based on the pepper market, a second launched by American silver coming from Seville (ending with the bankruptcy of Spain in 1557), and a third boom, after the stabilising Treaty of Cateau-Cambresis in 1559, based on the textiles industry. At the beginning of the 16th century Antwerp accounted for 40% of world trade. The boom-and-bust cycles and inflationary cost-of-living squeezed less-skilled workers.  In the century after 1541, the city's economy and population declined dramatically The Portuguese merchants left in 1549, and there was much less trade in English cloth.  Numerous financial bankruptcies  began around 1557. Amsterdam replaced Antwerp as the major trading center for the region.


=== Reformation era ===
The religious revolution of the Reformation erupted in violent riots in August 1566, as in other parts of the Low Countries. The regent Margaret, Duchess of Parma, was swept aside when Philip II sent the Duke of Alba at the head of an army the following summer. When the Eighty Years' War broke out in 1568, commercial trading between Antwerp and the Spanish port of Bilbao collapsed and became impossible. On 4 November 1576, Spanish soldiers sacked the city during the so-called Spanish Fury: 7,000 citizens were massacred, 800 houses were burnt down, and over £2 million sterling of damage was done.


=== Dutch revolt ===
Subsequently, the city joined the Union of Utrecht in 1579 and became the capital of the Dutch revolt. In 1585, Alessandro Farnese, Duke of Parma and Piacenza, captured it after a long siege and as part of the terms of surrender its Protestant citizens were given two years to settle their affairs before quitting the city. Most went to the United Provinces in the north, starting the Dutch Golden Age. Antwerp's banking was controlled for a generation by Genoa, and Amsterdam became the new trading centre.


=== 17th–19th centuries ===

The recognition of the independence of the United Provinces by the Treaty of Münster in 1648 stipulated that the Scheldt should be closed to navigation, which destroyed Antwerp's trading activities. This impediment remained in force until 1863, although the provisions were relaxed during French rule from 1795 to 1814, and also during the time Belgium formed part of the Kingdom of the United Netherlands (1815 to 1830). Antwerp had reached the lowest point in its fortunes in 1800, and its population had sunk to under 40,000, when Napoleon, realizing its strategic importance, assigned funds to enlarge the harbour by constructing a new dock (still named the Bonaparte Dock) and an access- lock and mole and deepening the Scheldt to allow for larger ships to approach Antwerp. Napoleon hoped that by making Antwerp's harbour the finest in Europe he would be able to counter the Port of London and hamper British growth. However, he was defeated at the Battle of Waterloo before he could see the plan through.

In 1830, the city was captured by the Belgian insurgents, but the citadel continued to be held by a Dutch garrison under General David Hendrik Chassé. For a time Chassé subjected the town to periodic bombardment which inflicted much damage, and at the end of 1832 the citadel itself was besieged by the French Northern Army commanded by Marechal Gerard. During this attack the town was further damaged. In December 1832, after a gallant defence, Chassé made an honourable surrender, ending the Siege of Antwerp (1832).Later that century, a double ring of Brialmont Fortresses was constructed some 10 km (6 mi)  from the city centre, as Antwerp was considered vital for the survival of the young Belgian state. And in 1894 Antwerp presented itself to the world via a World's Fair attended by 3 million.


=== 20th century ===

Antwerp was the first city to host the World Gymnastics Championships, in 1903. During World War I, the city became the fallback point of the Belgian Army after the defeat at Liège. The Siege of Antwerp lasted for 11 days, but the city was taken after heavy fighting by the German Army, and the Belgians were forced to retreat westwards. Antwerp remained under German occupation until the Armistice.
Antwerp hosted the 1920 Summer Olympics. 
During World War II, the city was an important strategic target because of its port. It was occupied by Germany in May 1940 and liberated by the British 11th Armoured Division on 4 September 1944. After this, the Germans attempted to destroy the Port of Antwerp, which was used by the Allies to bring new material ashore. Thousands of Rheinbote, V-1 and V-2 missiles were fired (more V-2s than used on all other targets during the entire war combined), causing severe damage to the city but failed to destroy the port due to poor accuracy. After the war, Antwerp, which had already had a sizeable Jewish population before the war, once again became a major European centre of Haredi (and particularly Hasidic) Orthodox Judaism.
A Ten-Year Plan for the port of Antwerp (1956–1965) expanded and modernized the port's infrastructure with national funding to build a set of canal docks. The broader aim was to facilitate the growth of the north-eastern Antwerp metropolitan region, which attracted new industry based on a flexible and strategic implementation of the project as a co-production between various authorities and private parties. The plan succeeded in extending the linear layout along the Scheldt river by connecting new satellite communities to the main strip.Starting in the 1990s, Antwerp rebranded itself as a world-class fashion centre. Emphasizing the avant-garde, it tried to compete with London, Milan, New York and Paris. It emerged from organized tourism and mega-cultural events.


== Municipality ==

The municipality comprises the city of Antwerp proper and several towns. It is divided into nine entities (districts):

Antwerp
Berchem
Berendrecht-Zandvliet-Lillo
Borgerhout
Deurne
Ekeren
Hoboken
Merksem
WilrijkIn 1958, in preparation of the 10-year development plan for the Port of Antwerp, the municipalities of Berendrecht-Zandvliet-Lillo were integrated into the city territory and lost their administrative independence. During the 1983 merger of municipalities, conducted by the Belgian government as an administrative simplification, the municipalities of Berchem, Borgerhout, Deurne, Ekeren, Hoboken, Merksem and Wilrijk were merged into the city. At that time the city was also divided into the districts mentioned above. Simultaneously, districts received an appointed district council; later district councils became elected bodies.


== Buildings and landmarks ==

In the 16th century, Antwerp was noted for the wealth of its citizens ("Antwerpia nummis"). The houses of these wealthy merchants and manufacturers have been preserved throughout the city. However, fire has destroyed several old buildings, such as the house of the Hanseatic League on the northern quays, in 1891. During World War II, the city also suffered considerable damage from V-bombs, and in recent years, other noteworthy buildings have been demolished for new developments.

Antwerp Zoo opened in 1843 and is one of the oldest in the world.
Antwerp City Hall dates from 1565, and is built primarily in Renaissance style.
Antwerp Central Station is a railway station designed by Louis Delacenserie which was completed in 1905.
Cathedral of Our Lady. This church was begun in the 14th century and finished in 1518. The church has four works by Rubens, viz. "The Descent from the Cross", "The Elevation of the Cross", "The Resurrection of Christ" and "The Assumption"
St. James' Church, is more ornate than the cathedral. It contains the remains of numerous famous nobles, among them a major part of the family of Rubens.
The Church of St. Paul has a baroque interior. It is a few hundred yards north of the Grote Markt
St. Andrew's Church
St. Charles Borromeo Church
Museum Vleeshuis (Butchers' Hall) is a fine Gothic brick-built building, situated a short distance to the North-West of the Grote Markt.
Plantin-Moretus Museum preserves the house of the printer Christoffel Plantijn and his successor Jan Moretus
The Saint-Boniface Church is an Anglican church and headseat of the archdeanery North-West Europe.
Boerentoren (Farmers' Tower) or KBC Tower, a 26-storey building built in 1932, is the oldest skyscraper in Europe. It is the tallest building in Antwerp and the second tallest structure after the Cathedral of our Lady. The building was designed by Emiel van Averbeke, R. Van Hoenacker and Jos Smolderen.
Royal Museum of Fine Arts
Museum Mayer van den Bergh, with works from the Gothic and Renaissance period in the Netherlands and Belgium, including paintings by Pieter Brueghel the Elder.
Rubenshuis is the former home and studio of Peter Paul Rubens (1577–1640) in Antwerp. It is now a museum.
Rockox House is the former 17th-century Residence of Nicolaas II Rockox, lord Mayor of Antwerp.
Bourse of Antwerp. Originally built 1531; extensively restored 1872; now Antwerp Trade Fair.
Palace of Justice, designed by the Richard Rogers Partnership, Arup and VK Studio, and opened by King Albert II, in April 2006. This building is the antithesis of the heavy, dark court building, designed by Joseph Poelaert, which dominates the skyline of Brussels. The courtrooms sit on top of six fingers that radiate from an airy central hall, and are surmounted by spires, which provide north light and resemble oast houses or the sails of barges on the nearby River Scheldt. It is built on the site of the old Zuid ("South") station, at the end of a magnificent 1.5 kilometres (1 mile) perspective at the southern end of Amerikalei. The road neatly disappears into an underpass under oval Bolivarplaats to join the motorway ring. This leaves peaceful surface access by foot, bicycle or tram (route 12). The building's highest 'sail' is 51 m (167 ft) high, has a floor area of 77,000 m2 (830,000 sq ft), and cost €130 million.
Zurenborg, a late-19th-century Belle Époque neighbourhood, on the border of Antwerp and Berchem, with many Art Nouveau architectural elements. The area counts as one of the most original Belle Époque urban expansion areas in Europe.
Museum aan de Stroom
Den Botaniek or Antwerp's Botanical Garden, created in 1825. Located in the city centre, at the Leopoldstraat, it covers an area of almost 1 hectare.
Harmonium Art museuM, a museum on pump organs in Klein-Willebroek
Museum of Contemporary Art (M HKA)


== Fortifications ==

Although Antwerp was formerly a fortified city, hardly anything remains of the former enceinte, only some remains of the city wall can be seen near the Vleeshuis museum at the corner of Bloedberg and Burchtgracht. A replica of a castle named Steen has been partly rebuilt near the Scheldt-quais in the 19th century.
Antwerp's development as a fortified city is documented between the 10th and the 20th century. The fortifications were developed in different phases:

10th century: fortification of the wharf with a wall and a ditch
12th and 13th century: canals (so called "vlieten" and "ruien") were made
16th century: Spanish fortifications
19th century: double ring of Brialmont forts around the city, dismantling of the Spanish fortifications
20th century: 1960 dismantling of the inner ring of forts, decommissioning of the outer ring of forts


== Demographics ==


=== Historical population ===

This is the population of the city of Antwerp only, not of the larger current municipality of the same name.


=== Minorities ===
In 2010, 36% to 39% of the inhabitants of Antwerp had a migrant background. A study projects that in 2020, 55% of the population will be of migrant background.


==== Jewish community ====

After The Holocaust and the murder of its many Jews, Antwerp became a major centre for Orthodox Jews. At present, about 15,000 Haredi Jews, many of them Hasidic, live in Antwerp. The city has three official Jewish Congregations: Shomrei Hadass, headed by Rabbi Dovid Moishe Lieberman, Machsike Hadass, headed by Rabbi Aron Schiff  (formerly by Chief Rabbi Chaim Kreiswirth) and the Portuguese Community Ben Moshe. Antwerp has an extensive network of synagogues, shops, schools and organizations. Significant Hasidic movements in Antwerp include Pshevorsk, based in Antwerp, as well as branches of Satmar, Belz, Bobov, Ger, Skver, Klausenburg, Vizhnitz and several others. Rabbi Chaim Kreiswirth, chief rabbi of the Machsike Hadas community, who died in 2001, was arguably one of the better known personalities to have been based in Antwerp. An attempt to have a street named after him has received the support of the Town Hall and is in the process of being implemented.


==== Jain community ====

The Jains in Belgium are estimated to be around about 1,500 people. The majority live in Antwerp, mostly involved in the very lucrative diamond business. Belgian Indian Jains control two-thirds of the rough diamonds trade and supplied India with roughly 36% of their rough diamonds. A major temple, with a cultural centre, has been built in Antwerp (Wilrijk).  Mr Ramesh Mehta, a Jain, is a full-fledged member of the Belgian Council of Religious Leaders, put up on 17 December 2009.


==== Armenian community ====

There are significant Armenian communities that reside in Antwerp, many of them are descendants of traders who settled during the 19th century. Most Armenian Belgians are adherents of the Armenian Apostolic Church, with a smaller numbers are adherents of the Armenian Catholic Church and Armenian Evangelical Church.
One of the important sectors that Armenian communities in Antwerp excel and involved in is the diamond trade business, that based primarily in the diamond district. Some of the famous Armenian families involved in the diamond business in the city are the Artinians, Arslanians, Aslanians, Barsamians and the Osganians.


== Economy ==


=== Port ===
According to the American Association of Port Authorities, the port of Antwerp was the seventeenth largest (by tonnage) port in the world in 2005 and second only to Rotterdam in Europe. It handled 235.2 million tons of cargo in 2018. Importantly it handles high volumes of economically attractive general and project cargo, as well as bulk cargo. Antwerp's docklands, with five oil refineries, are home to a massive concentration of petrochemical industries, second only to the petrochemical cluster in Houston, Texas. Electricity generation is also an important activity, with four nuclear power plants at Doel, a conventional power station in Kallo, as well as several smaller combined cycle plants. There is a wind farm in the northern part of the port area. There are plans to extend this in the period 2014–2020.  The old Belgian bluestone quays bordering the Scheldt for a distance of 5.6 km (3.5 mi) to the north and south of the city centre have been retained for their sentimental value and are used mainly by cruise ships and short sea shipping.


=== Diamonds ===
Antwerp's other great mainstay is the diamond trade that takes place largely within the diamond district. 85 percent of the world's rough diamonds pass through the district annually, and in 2011 turnover in the industry was $56 billion. The city has four diamond bourses: the Diamond Club of Antwerp, the Beurs voor Diamanthandel, the Antwerpsche Diamantkring and the Vrije Diamanthandel. Antwerp's history in the diamond trade dates back to as early as the sixteenth century, with the first diamond cutters guild being introduced in 1584. The industry never disappeared from Antwerp, and even experienced a second boom in the early twentieth century. By the year 1924, Antwerp had over 13,000 diamond finishers. Since World War II families of the large Hasidic Jewish community have dominated Antwerp's diamond trading industry, although the last two decades have seen Indian and Maronite Christian from Lebanon and Armenian, traders become increasingly important.Antwerp World Diamond Centre, (AWDC) the successor to the Hoge Raad voor Diamant, plays an important role in setting standards, regulating professional ethics, training and promoting the interests of Antwerp as the capital of the diamond industry. However, in recent years Antwerp has seen a downturn in the diamond business, with the industry shifting to cheaper labor markets such as Dubai or India.


== Transportation ==


=== Road ===
A six-lane motorway bypass encircles much of the city centre and runs through the urban residential area of Antwerp. Known locally as the "Ring" it offers motorway connections to Brussels, Hasselt and Liège, Ghent, Lille and Bruges and Breda and Bergen op Zoom (Netherlands). The banks of the Scheldt are linked by three road tunnels (in order of construction): the Waasland Tunnel (1934), the Kennedy Tunnel (1967) and the Liefkenshoek Tunnel (1991).
Daily congestion on the Ring led to a fourth high-volume highway link called the "Oosterweelconnection" being proposed. It would have entailed the construction of a long viaduct and bridge (the Lange Wapper) over the docks on the north side of the city in combination with the widening of the existing motorway into a 14-lane motorway; these plans were eventually rejected in a 2009 public referendum.In September 2010 the Flemish Government decided to replace the bridge by a series of tunnels. There are ideas to cover the Ring in a similar way as happened around Paris, Hamburg, Madrid and other cities. This would reconnect the city with its suburbs and would provide development opportunities to accommodate part of the foreseen population growth in Antwerp which currently are not possible because of the pollution and noise generated by the traffic on the Ring. An old plan to build an R2 outer ring road outside the built up urban area around the Antwerp agglomeration for port related traffic and transit traffic never materialized.


=== Rail ===

Antwerp is the focus of lines to the north to Essen and the Netherlands, east to Turnhout, south to Mechelen, Brussels and Charleroi, and southwest to Ghent and Ostend. It is served by international trains to Amsterdam and Paris, and national trains to Ghent, Bruges, Ostend, Brussels, Charleroi, Hasselt, Liège, Leuven and Turnhout.
Antwerp Central station is an architectural monument in itself, and is mentioned in W G Sebald's haunting novel Austerlitz. Prior to the completion in 2007 of a tunnel that runs northwards under the city centre to emerge at the old Antwerp Dam station, Central was a terminus. Trains from Brussels to the Netherlands had to either reverse at Central or call only at Berchem station, 2 kilometres (1 mile) to the south, and then describe a semicircle to the east, round the Singel. Now, they call at the new lower level of the station before continuing in the same direction.
Antwerp is also home to Antwerpen-Noord, the largest classification yard for freight in Belgium and second largest in Europe. The majority of freight trains in Belgium depart from or arrive here. It has two classification humps and over a hundred tracks.


=== Public transportation ===
The city has a web of tram and bus lines operated by De Lijn and providing access to the city centre, suburbs and the Left Bank. The tram network has 12 lines, of which the underground section is called the "premetro" and includes a tunnel under the river. The Franklin Rooseveltplaats functions as the city's main hub for local and regional bus lines.


=== Air ===

A small airport, Antwerp International Airport, is located in the district of Deurne, with passenger service to various European destinations. A bus service connects the airport to the city centre.
The now defunct VLM Airlines had its head office on the grounds of Antwerp International Airport. This office is also CityJet's Antwerp office. When VG Airlines (Delsey Airlines) existed, its head office was located in the district of Merksem.Belgium's major international airport, Brussels Airport, is about 45 kilometres (28 miles) from the city of Antwerp, and connects the city worldwide. It is connected to the city centre by bus, and also by train. The new Diabolo rail connection provides a direct fast train connection between Antwerp and Brussels Airport as of the summer of 2012.
There is also a direct rail service between Antwerp (calling at Central and Berchem stations) and Charleroi South station, with a connecting buslink to Brussels South Charleroi Airport, which runs twice every hour on working days.
The runway has increased in length, and there is now direct connectivity to Spain, United Kingdom, Germany, France, Italy, and Greece from the city of Antwerp.
In September 2019 Air Antwerp began operations with their first route to London City Airport with old VLM Airlines Fokker 50's.


== Politics ==


=== City council ===
The current city council was elected in the October 2018 elections.
The current majority consists of N-VA, sp.a and Open Vld, led by mayor Bart De Wever (N-VA).


=== Former mayors ===

In the 16th and 17th century important mayors include Philips of Marnix, Lord of Saint-Aldegonde, Anthony van Stralen, Lord of Merksem and Nicolaas II Rockox.
In the early years after Belgian independence, Antwerp was governed by Catholic-Unionist mayors. Between 1848 and 1921, all mayors were from the Liberal Party (except for the so-called Meeting-intermezzo between 1863 and 1872). Between 1921 and 1932, the city had a Catholic mayor again: Frans Van Cauwelaert.
From 1932 onwards and up until 2013, all mayors belonged to the Social Democrat party: Camille Huysmans, Lode Craeybeckx, Frans Detiège and Mathilde Schroyens, and after the municipality fusion: Bob Cools, Leona Detiège en Patrick Janssens. Since 2013, the mayor is the Flemish nationalist Bart De Wever, belonging to the Flemish separatist party N-VA (New Flemish Alliance).


== Climate ==
Antwerp has an oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb) similar to that of Southern England, while being far enough inland to build up summer warmth above 23 °C (73 °F) average highs for both July and August. Winters are more dominated by the maritime currents instead, with temps being heavily moderated.


== Culture ==
Antwerp had an artistic reputation in the 17th century, based on its school of painting, which included Rubens, Van Dyck, Jordaens, the Teniers and many others.

Informally, most Antverpians (in Dutch Antwerpenaren, people from Antwerp) speak Antverpian daily (in Dutch Antwerps), a dialect that Dutch-speakers know as distinctive from other Brabantic dialects for its characteristic pronunciation of vowels: an 'aw' sound approximately like that in 'bore' is used for one of its long 'a'-sounds while other short 'a's are very sharp like the 'a' in 'hat'. The Echt Antwaarps Teater ("Authentic Antverpian Theatre") brings the dialect on stage.


=== Fashion ===
Antwerp is a rising fashion city, and has produced designers such as the Antwerp Six. The city has a cult status in the fashion world, due to the Royal Academy of Fine Arts, one of the most important fashion academies in the world. It has served as the learning centre for many Belgian fashion designers. Since the 1980s, several graduates of the Belgian Royal Academy of Fine Arts have become internationally successful fashion designers in Antwerp. The city has had a huge influence on other Belgian fashion designers such as Raf Simons, Veronique Branquinho, Olivier Theyskens and Kris Van Assche.


=== Local products ===
Antwerp is famous for its local products. In August every year the Bollekesfeest takes place. The Bollekesfeest is a showcase for such local products as Bolleke, an amber beer from the De Koninck Brewery. The Mokatine sweets made by Confiserie Roodthooft, Elixir D'Anvers, a locally made liquor, locally roasted coffee from Koffie Verheyen, sugar from Candico, Poolster pickled herring and Equinox horse meat, are other examples of local specialities. One of the most known products of the city are its biscuits, the Antwerpse Handjes, literally "Antwerp Hands". Usually made from a short pastry with almonds or milk chocolate, they symbolize the Antwerp trademark and folklore. The local products are represented by a non-profit organization, Streekproducten Provincie Antwerpen vzw.


=== Missions to seafarers ===
A number of Christian missions to seafarers are based in Antwerp, notably on the Italiëlei. These include the Mission to Seafarers, British & International Sailors' Society, the Finnish Seamen's Mission, the Norwegian Sjømannskirken and the Apostleship of the Sea. They provide cafeterias, cultural and social activities as well as religious services.


=== Music ===
Antwerp is the home of the Antwerp Jazz Club (AJC), founded in 1938 and located on the square Grote Markt since 1994.The band dEUS was formed in 1991 in Antwerp. dEUS began their career as a covers band, but soon began writing their own material. Their musical influences range from folk and punk to jazz and progressive rock.


=== Music festivals ===
Cultuurmarkt van Vlaanderen is a musical festival and a touristic attraction that takes place annually on the final Sunday of August in the city center of Antwerp. Where international and local musicians and actors, present their stage and street performances.Linkerwoofer is a pop-rock music festival located at the left bank of the Scheldt. This music festival starts in August and mostly local Belgian musicians play and perform in this event.Other popular festivals Fire Is Gold, and focuses more on urban music, and Summerfestival.


=== World Choir Games ===
The city of Antwerp will co-host the 2020 World Choir Games together with the city of Ghent. Organised by the Interkultur Foundation, the World Choir Games is the biggest choral competition and festival in the world.


== Sport ==

Antwerp held the 1920 Summer Olympics, which were the first games after the First World War and also the only ones to be held in Belgium. The road cycling events took place in the streets of the city.Royal Antwerp F.C., currently playing in the Belgian First Division, were founded in 1880 and is known as 'The Great Old' for being the first club registered to the Royal Belgian Football Association in 1895. Since 1998, the club has taken Manchester United players on loan in an official partnership. Another club in the city was Beerschot VAC, founded in 1899 by former Royal Antwerp players. They played at the Olympisch Stadion, the main venue of the 1920 Olympics. Nowadays KFCO Beerschot Wilrijk plays at the Olympisch Stadion in the Belgian Second Division.
The Antwerp Giants play in Basketball League Belgium and Topvolley Antwerpen play in the Belgium men's volleyball League.
For the year 2013, Antwerp was awarded the title of European Capital of Sport.
Antwerp hosted the 2013 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships.
Antwerp hosted the start of stage 3 of the 2015 Tour de France on 6 July 2015.


== Higher education ==

Antwerp has a university and several colleges. The University of Antwerp  (Universiteit Antwerpen) was established in 2003, following the merger of the RUCA, UFSIA and UIA institutes. Their roots go back to 1852. The University has approximately 23,000 registered students, making it the third-largest university in Flanders, as well as 1,800 foreign students. It has 7 faculties, spread over four campus locations in the city centre and in the south of the city.
The city has several colleges, including Antwerp Management School (AMS), Charlemagne University College (Karel de Grote Hogeschool), Plantin University College (Plantijn Hogeschool), and Artesis University College (Artesis Hogeschool). Artesis University College has about 8,600 students and 1,600 staff, and Charlemagne University College has about 10,000 students and 1,300 staff. Plantin University College has approximately 3,700 students.

This small castle is used for the training of children and youngsters in art. It is small but intersting for a short visit.

Good well preserved castle overlooking the harbour. There is a good café downstairs and an area at the back that tells the story of town the Steen was used during the war. The statue at the front was apparently defaced by the Jesuits a few centuries ago,

this a treasure , one of the oldest standing castles in antwerpen, it will take you back in time witht he history of the castle and the people who live there and all the history of the castle itself standing onthe river banks alone with a view tot he other side of the side of
The castle is picturesque as you walk out to the river from the City Hall. You can't go in, but interesting scenery.
This castle isn't open. Its fine to look at but you can't go in . Right on the river bank and interesting to look at only.
Right on the cost of the river, worth taking a trip to it once in Antwerp. Will not take more than 15min, great to take a photo with, but also great views from the castle. Highly recommend.
We did not get inside the fortress but it is impressive none the less. The views from the water are outstanding with the city in the backdrop.
You won't miss this castle if you are walking around town !! Very big ! Always fun to walk around a castle !!!

this castle stands on the river with it's beautiful Romanesque style , it's a good place to spend some good time there
There is nothing much to do here but off-course can take some nice pictures around. You can also see the one of the oldest Sand clock here. Entry is free and 10min walkable from Town hall.

It is a nice, old place next to the river. With the Narrow corridors and smaller rooms anyone can feel that we went back in time. It is interesting that at the ground floor there is a room for the oldest sandglass of the world (or they say that). At higher floors the view is
A short visit, but very nice. It is interesting to see the differences in the construction, between the original part and what was recovered.

I don't know if you can go inside because when I visited it, it maybe could be closed because of public holiday. But from the outside it's nice to watch the medieval architecture (it's the oldest building in Antwerp).

its very small and on the bank of river. Just go through it and admire its beauty. and you will see great view of river. after long day you can sit on the bank of river and enjoy your time relaxing or doing picnic
You can walk through but there is not much to visit. There is a quirky cafe, but not much history to see.
The castle is beautiful on the outside and definitely worth a stop to have a closer look and take pictures . Not much to see inside !

Since our cruise boat was using the pier near to this castle, so we have many chances to crossed by this tourist spots and took adequate photos from different angles. By the way, there was a cafe and washroom on basement level and worth for a visit by tourists.
Lovely castle on the waterfront. Bridges and turrets, statues and architectural pieces. Should be seen from at least 3 sides and probably from the river.
It looks great from a distance enticing you in to find a cafe and children's workshop where there should be a great history story. What a waste! No fee for the disappointment.
walking down by the river is always an attraction and as you stroll you see this and pass through it in two minutes, interesting to see but don't make an effort to go though unless you are nearby
a funny little castle with original stocks in place, you can sit in them while the person you are with takes a photo, other interesting things to do inside as well, or have a sit down with a coffee
The castle has mostly been demolished. But it is worth a look around but do not expect to much as there is not much left of it.
Sits by the river, and now appears to be a theatre. While can't go inside, can walk around outside. Pretty cool, and nice views up top as well.

Just about a 25-30 minute walk from Antwerp Central Station, through the main shopping streets, towards Grote Markt, Cathedral and river. You can freely walk up into the castle and around it to enjoy the river views.

Steen castle sits on the bank of the Schelde river and is at the heart of the original Antwerp. The lower and older part of the castle dates from the 1000s while the top and newer part dates from 1500s-1600s. Originally, the houses of the town crowded around the castle but
Nice small castle, nothing extra to see, but good location. Accessible with stroller as well. Inside cafe baby and small kids friendly.

Steen Castle, locally known as Het Steen (arond in 1520), which translates to 'The Stone'. It`s normal for Flemish provinces: for instance the castle in Gehnt names as Gravensteen. it was one of the earliest buildings in Antwerp constructed with stones at a time when most houses

Antwerp's oldest building used to house the maritime museum until the collection became part of the MAS. Nowadays a child friendly meeting place for young and old, especially in summer. Walk through the gate on the elevated walk from Noorder- to Zuiderterras.
This is free to enter and legend has it is the original for Disney's castle. Take a walk around the ramparts and enjoy the river views
Nice and beautiful place to walk around and lovely views to the river! I really recommend this visit!!
This is a lovely old building which is somewhat spoilt by the surrounding bits and pieces attached. So much more could be made of this really historic landmark.
This is a nice place to walk around inside the Steen as well as around the building there is walking bridge. Nice view of the Schelde and old Antwerp. Nearby De Grote Markt and many cafe's around.
A quick visit to Steenplein can be complete by checking out the castle that is a nice viewpoint of the river as well. There's a winter market & fair that one can visit in the winter.
Very beautifully decorated at Christmas time in the evening, make sure to take a few moments to get some pictures with all the lights.
In the winter nights its is nicely lit up with blue light. Awesome to see and walk around this amazing castle.

I walked by here by mistake while I was walking along the water. I figured I'd stop to check it out. The inside of the castle was not open when I was there but from the outside, it's pretty cool. Lots of people snapping pictures here and they were setting up for a Christmas

is just a small castle near the Schelde, nice to see it also because is free and very close to other nice squares and buildings, but when it comes Christmas time it becomes a must see
