The park would be twice as good if there were...SIGNS indicating how to get to the st least the main attractions!! The park is well-kept and has lots of animals but it is IMPOSSIBLE to find your way around...a real pity!

It's a really nice place to be. Interesting animals, lots of plants and cool playgrounds are worth highlighting. Your experience however may loose a part of its charm on a crowded day. Parking traffic is not well managed leading to huge mess and wasted time. There's also not

Planckendael was great fun for the young kids in our group (and some kid-at-heart adults too). The park is pretty huge. The animal enclosures are divided into themes of continents, and that, put together with the many eye-catching, interactive information plaques that litter

In opposite to its counterpart Zoo Antwerpen, you can always see the work and constant changing in this zoo. Recent adding of a cool elephant park and a large giraffe pavillion ads to it's splendor. It's very nice for children too...some parts like the African village though,
Well planted gardens and enclosures. well spaced large enclosures so expect a long walk Easy parking. various food outlets - usual zoo prices

Great plan of the zoo makes you enjoy the different locations of the world with its animals. A great variety of animals, and playgrounds. Enough facilities when they're opened. We were unlucky to be here during the week, after summer holiday, so only one restaurant (Azia) was
Great animal park, very good for family outings. A lot of beautiful animals to be seen. Very good price quality.

Super great place , kids and we had so much fun there . A really well kept "zoo" . This is more like a forest kind of theme park . Animals look happy and well treated , clean and lots of things to do for the kids , slides, parks, rafts, climbing bridges and most animals roam

My husband, daughter (5 years old) and I all visited Planckendael and absolutely loved it. The ropes are well made, and each climbing unit has a net underneath, making it safe and comfortable so that you can spend your energy climbing instead of worrying about falling or wearing
A great zoo to visit with a variety of animals from various countries. Good outing for a day for the entire family. It has something to offer everyone in the family.

Took our 6 year old and had a fantastic time. The continent theme was very well done and the animals had plenty of space. The penguin enclosure is awesome and there is plenty to do for children if they want to let off steam. Would definitely go again.

Great zoo with 5 continent theme sites, each home to their native inhabitants. Some of the animals come close enough to touch (penguin, storck, ...), but we tell our kid not to. Relaxed strolling from one place to the next, even with small kids (3Y) and a stroller for the baby.

Probably my daughter's (and my) favorite "exhibit" was the penguin display; they were, indeed close enough to touch. Please don't, however. There are also various furry animals (names now forgotten) that you can touch and indeed will crawl over you. Fun for the kids, though I

The zoo is spread over a rather large area. The enclosures are all quite big and the animals look well taken care of. The variety of animals isn't that great thug, unless you like birds. The penguin enclosure is fantastic. You get to walk through the middle of it and the

There actually appear to be more play areas than animals, but our twin 3 1/2 year-olds had a wonderful time. It was a very hot day and we were able to find plenty of shade. Prices in the food concessions were only a little high and the selection was good. We saw elephants,
Several visits and I never get tired of it. Well-kept park, with continuous efforts for extensions and new attractions for kids. Large parking, ample food supplies for different budgets.

This is a must to see, this Zoo is one of the best and the animals are so good looking! Sometimes you really feel as if you are walking in Asia while your stroll through the Asia area. Of course the pinguin area is one of the best, at least for me. If you are lucky one of those

Planckendael is not just an ordinary zoo. They are looking for special experiences such as walking together with pinguins. The walking loops per continent are great. Combing different species in one place give a new experience.

Planckendael is an open space zoo, better described as an "animal park". Continuous efforts are being made to keep the park up to date! Perfect for kids since there is a small petting zoo including goats and llamas :)

Had the best Sunday possible - we were three generations thoroughly enjoying ourselves and the animals in a beautiful park very close to Brussels. It's a perfect crossover between a zoo and a huge playground. Beautifully laid out in different continents with many details giving

This zoo was amazing! Absolutely beautiful, by far the best zoo I've ever been too. So much to do and we didn't even see everything. You could go two days running. Fantastic lay out, with multiple parks and play areas to keep children busy. Beautiful large enclosures, where the

In most animal parks, you can only watch the animals in a small environment, so they would allways be close to the visitor. In Plankendael, animals can walk and run in a large habitat, avoiding them to be packed together. A realy well kept park !

This is a really good animal park. The attention to detail with all of the enclosures is impressive and its a very pleasant place to walk around. The kids love it and there are things to look at in every direction. There is a good balance of places to eat, picnic areas, kids

After 15 years I went back to Planckendael in Mechelen, Belgium, and it was a real poitive surprise to me. The park is divided into 5 continnets and you can see animals in a nearly normal environment. Today the have also rangers who make an educative trip for kids possible. If
Big zoo with a lot of different animals to see and with many attractions for children. Every year there is something new to discover.

Very nice zoo, really worth a visit! The most animals have a large space where they can run around. The place is safe and give a natural atmosphere what's pretty unique. Children will like it a lot and so do i :-). There is also a place to eat and to drink. You can easily reach

Great park, lovely to walk around in, have a picknick and see all the animals. The animals are not in cages locked up, but have nice piece of land to enjoy themselves.

Little children love the many play zones; they are just shortly interested in animals. Planckendael therefor is the ideal location. Just try to go there when the weather is not too good; otherwise it can be a little bit too overcrowded, even at Planckendael ...

we had been recommended to visit whilst we were in the area and were not disappointed. Park is very spacious with plenty of large areas for the animals, not giving the cramped feel like some zoo's. Good range of animals to see and easy to find with plenty of parking if driving.

I was sold on going here when i heard they had koalas. It then got better when i found out they had snow leopards! This place is so much bigger than you'd think, with such a variety of animals it'll keep you entertained all day. There are various talks or feeding hours that you

Although I live in DOM, my home address is a bare 10 minutes from Plankendael. Last week I watched a Plankendael promotion on TV and could barely believe what I saw. This is much more than just a little animal farm like many people believe. Animals from all over teh world, It is

No animals in small cages here. It's a large park, but not too big to walk with kids. The animals get to live in communities (mixed animals) in decent size enclusures in a green environment. Perfect day out with kids! (our 5 year old goes several times per year since he was 2).
We had discussed the year before that we should visit and this year we did; what a great place to go! our 2 year old had the time of her life and we must return next time around...Fantastic!

also quite pricey for a day. The best part was the fact that from Mechelen Railway station you can take a boat (well, a converted Barge) to the back of the park so avoiding all the Q's and car parking hassles and presumably charges.

Lots of different animals and this all in a very nice environmental setting. There are also several small playgrounds for children. Food and beverages are a bit expensive and not comparable with the quality of an average Belgian restaurant.

Planckendael is a relatively new zoo, connected to the much older Antwerp Zoo. There is plenty of space for the animals to roam; the Continents which form the various sections of the Zoo are downright fun in the way they incorporate themes of their Continent, and there's plenty

The zoo itself is very nice, but the kids and some adults, will really enjoy doing the climbing areas to see the zoo from higher! It also has a great park for kids to play and adults to have a cup of coffee!

a extreme child friendly excursion is to go the zoo with the boat. Park the car around Mechelen railwaystation and at Comabridge , you can take one of the yellow boates (starting every 30 min) to Planckendael zoo. after 15 min with the boat you end up at the entry at the back
Love how close you can get to the animals and the wide space the animals have to enjoy nature! Glad to see zoo's no longer keep animals in small cages!
We go there at least once every 2 months since over 5 years. The kids love it, lots of space, friendly staff and great playing area's.
While visiting the town of Mechelen, we took a detour and spent a day at Plankendael zoo. Absolutely worthwhile, well kept zoo, broad variety of animals.

Very beautiful surrounding. Much more peaceful and child friendly than the zoo of Antwerp. The Zoo of Antwerp is also nice though. You can get quite close to the animals and the variety of animals is huge. Perfect for a day out with the kids
Very nice park in which even a big crowd comes to rest. Much beter than his big brother in Antwerp. More accomodations to rest should be welcome.

Park visited with the kids and they loved it very much, had been awhile since I've been there myself. There is lately changed and modernized a lot so I did not recognize it anymore and was pleasantly surprised. The new residence of the elephants is a highlight and the giraffes

Nobody in the know takes their kids to the zoo in Antwerp. It is right in the middle of town near the train station and there is insufficient space for the animals. Planckendael is hardly the best place I've ever been to, but if you have kids, it's one of the best places in

Near to Mechelen, some 25 kms from Antwerp you will find this wonderful zoo in the countryside. It is great to visit with children, many playgrounds. Recent modernizations show the animals in their (more) natural surroundings.

It was a few years since my last visit, but it amazed me how much investments were made to upgrade their grounds to a level where you can't talk about "just another zoo" anymore. We have no children, but enjoyed every second in this amazing park. Congrats for the new elephant

Me and my husband visited Planckendael with oud two kids (3y and almost 2y old) and my parents. We all had a great time. Although it's a zoo, there's lots of space... for the animals as well as for the visitors. For my kids, the visit to the little petting zoo (which is just one
Planckendael is in a sense nice zoo. We have a yearly subscription. As a total concept zoo, planckendael still has a way to go.

Always been my favorite, I've been to Antwerp & Planckendael last year. In Planckendael there are more animals, with much more space. In the middle of "the green". Really fan of the giraffes -area and african village. After 15 years, the raft is still fun.

I love Planckendael, much more than any regular Zoo. It has wide walking lanes, lots of flowers, beautiful trees and the animal domains are well spread out through the park. Also, the animals have a fairly big space (it remains a zoo, though) to move around. There are picnic

great space for animal live. visit and learn more about the animals and elephants. Marvelous park with great promenades and good food to
Almost all the animals were tucked away because of the cold. Understandable but then they shouldn't charge the full entranceprice.

I found it to be yet another zoo like other zoos. But it is well maintained and there are several things to do here. A good day of outing and for the people with family there is plenty for kids to keep them busy here.

With the new stay for the elephants, Planckendael is now certainly a 'full grown' zoo. Their residence is constructed like an Indian temple. The zoo has a continental format and you can find different animals in a very good imitation of their natural habitat. Another spectacular

the animals have a lot of space and the enviroment is adapted there is a great playing area for children
A big park with lots of animals. perfect for a day out with the kids. And stil more en more enlarging.

This is a very well-kept zoo with plenty of space for the animals which all look well-fed and well-kept. When the children get fed up with looking at the animals they can head for the rope walkways and climbing nets in the trees which will keep them amused for hours.

A great zoo, reachable via Train(Mechelen)+boat, or via car. The animals have plenty of space and the public has great overviews to see the animals in a 'naturally' environment. Phantastic for children!

have spent many pleasant afternoons with the kids over the years - nice open spaces so never appears too crowded with a great playgarden to end the visit off with while parents have a drink at the café

No other zoo has this free and realistic approach to watching animals. A map is needed to find the things you want to see, else a labyrinth. A bit pricy but the abo is good value for money. Democratic food and drinks available.
Animals look reasonably happy and well looked after. A great day out though very crowded in school holidays. Not surprising really. Not cheap either but at least not as expensive as London zoo !

As an experienced wildlife traveler, it still is difficult to accept seeing wild animals in a zoo when I'm used to seeing them on African plains or Asian forests. But all in all Plankendael tries to give the animals large, open spaces with natural boundaries, like water ponds,
It is a great place to walk around. I admit, there is something evil about a zoo and locking up animals but at least here the animals are surrounded by green

It is a personal thing, I admit. I hate to see animals behind bars or otherwise constrained. Planckendael is better than the Antwerp Zoo (of which it is a branch) but it still is a poor sight to someone who has seen e.g. elephants roaming in the wild. It is pathetic.
large zoo in the area of Mechelen/Leuven. regularly new exhibits. nice for a walk while admiring the animals in their natural setting.

For tourists this may be a bit too far from other main sights, but if you have a longer stay in Belgium, and you have kids it's a must. Not only there are lots of animals in wide enclosures, but also some very large playgrounds.

This park or zoo is amazing for outeries with the family. The entrance fee is a bit high but totally worth it. It's a nice place to be, sitting on a bench or walking around the big gardens viewing the animal kingdom

It's nice to walk around and see different animals that aren't living in a cramped space. Especially the children are fond of this: the playground for children is also nice! Worth a visit if you have a free day!

We have a subscription to this Zoo, which basically says it all: whenever you go there, there's always something new to discover. our kids love the place, and with the great playground at the exit, you always finish the day on a positive note.
More space for the animals, often in social groups etc. You have a better view on them and the park itself is worth the walk. Absolutely a must-do
Plankendael is nice to wonder around, for a zoo there is a lot of space and it gives more the idea of a park with exotic animals than the typical zoo.

At the time I visited this zoo the last time, a big part was under re-construction. But I know the place from before. Now that the construction works are finished and the new home for the elephants built, I will definitely go again.

This zoo is perfect for a day out. There are lots of animals and playgrounds and even a farm where kids of adults can touch the goats an sheep. The parc is big and it takes 4 to 6 hours if you want to see everything. Too bad you have to pay for the parking. You can also eat here

if you like animals it's better to go to Plankendael ok it's not in antwerp but it's only 25km aside and a bigger park where you have the impression that the animals are better of - it's also a nicer place to walk and enjoy nature
Quiet, amazing and huge zoo ! Lots of interactives for the young ones. Playground areas on several spots in the park. Friendly staff. Restaurants with good quality f&b.
Very nice big zoo. Amazing for children, behind every corner is a playground. Very well maintained
Animal zoo in a natural setting, great for kids. playgrounds.... Better than the Antwerp zoo.
The little ones and the bigger ones love this zoo.
This park combines wildlife with a walk in the park. Nicely done and certainly worth a visit

This is not only a Zoo, but also a conservation park; they have breeding programs for endangered species. The zoo animals are divided over 5 Continents and with natural looking settings. The compounds of the animals are big, and there are educational signs. There is a lot of

Very cool place to visit as soon as the weather lets you. No extreme good weather needed, always a joy to visit. You can do a small or a long tour, easy access for wheelchairs. At the end of the tour, there is a very nice caferaria, so keep a little place in your stomach for a
This is just a wonderful place to take your kids to. Take something to eat or eat at the many options there. You can manage to spend the whole day there without getting bored.

Excellent to go on a sunny day but be carefull if it is a bit cloudy cause the park is huge and if it starts raining once you are already there you might get back to your car completely wet. Some parts have been under renovation forever. But animals have nice space for

This animal park is very close to the city of Mechelen. You can get there by car, bus or even by boat!! Besides all the animals (this summer the new elephant park is opening), there are also lots of play gardens and restaurants.
Belgium's best zoo. Clean and lots of space for the animals. Very Green. Lots of playgrounds for the kids.
if you want to relax and let your kids run around, looking at animals and playing on a playground, it is ok. if you are adult and looking for an exciting day - stay away
the zoo is expanding and renovating here, a perfect place for family outings : do try to get here from antwerp with the train/boat connection !!!
Very nice place to see with kids, great animals, great playgrounds. Fast food a bit disappointing, but overall definitely worth a trip.

Planckendael is a subsidiary of the Antwep Zoo, but here the animals have a lot more space than in Antwerp. You can get there by train/boat (combination ticket) or by bus and it is fun, especially with children.

This is a very nice place to visit when the weather is nice. Unfortunately, here in Belgium we don't have that many warm, sunny days, so you really need to pick a good day to go to Planckendael. It can be very nice on a great summer day, but I think there's not much to do there

What a nice zoo - very nicely laid out and well organized. Our 3-year old daughter loved it, and so did we. Highly varied population of animals (loved the kangaroos!). Even though it's a large zoo, it has a quite 'compact' feel, and walk from the parking isn't too far either.

Plankendael is a part of the National Zoo, its a cooperation with the zoo in Antwerp. Its well maintained and the animals have lots of space to live. You can have a nice walk in the park and enjoy the beauty of nature. There are themes build in the park such as African village,

This zoo is very large and will probably take you a whole day took walk and look around. Parking is close and not too expensive. The food available on the premises is fresh en good, although a bit expensive.
Park is big enough to walk around all day, very nice trip and decent "selection" of animals available.
beautifull! i would encourage you! i have been there before and i liked it very much.
Perfect for half a day with the kids, enjoy your own picnic or make your choice in the restaurant/on the terrace.
Very nice zoo for young and old. In summer, take the boat from the Central station in Mechelen to Planckendael.

This zoo is great. It has a lot of animals and loads of fun and interactive things for the kids to do. My daughter loved the tree top walk, the canoo and the other play things we found on our way through the zoo. I found it a bit hard to find my way around the zoo. Even though

The zoo is located near Mechelen, but it's easy to reach with public transport ( from Mechelen station bus 284/285 10 min drive). In the summer there is also a boat. Its a very nice and clean zoo, with different areas( Azie, Afrika) The zoo is childfriendly, with a lot of toys

Great place to visit with the kids, or simply if you are an animal fan. In april all the storks were coming in and commencing with their nesting - a great sight to behold. Apart from that there are the geografically sorted areas. I loved the "Asia house", with the gibbons,

We live close to Planckendael and it is the place to spend time with children. Also good to get away from daily things and go back to a park where you can be alone. Nice for an hour walk or a whole Sunday afternoon. Very clean and well organized and the second best thing to real

text.wiki:
Fort Breendonk (Dutch: Fort van Breendonk, French: Fort de Breendonk) is a former military installation at Breendonk, near Mechelen, in Belgium which served as a Nazi prison camp (Auffanglager) during the German occupation of Belgium during World War II.
Fort Breendonk was originally built for the Belgian Army between 1906-13 as part of the second ring of defenses of the National Redoubt protecting the important port-city of Antwerp. It was covered by a five-metre thick layer of soil for defense against bombings, a water-filled moat and measured 656 by 984 feet (200 by 300 m).During World War II, the fort was requisitioned by the Germans as a prison camp for detaining Belgian political dissidents, captured resistance members and Jews. Although technically a prison rather than a concentration camp, the Fort was infamous for its prisoners' poor living conditions and for the use of torture. Most prisoners who were detained at the camp were later transferred to larger concentration camps in Eastern Europe. Of the 3,590 prisoners known to have been imprisoned at Breendonk, 303 died or were executed within the fort itself but as many as 1,741 died subsequently in other camps before the end of the war.Today, the site is a national memorial and museum which is open to the public.


== Construction and military use ==

Fort Breendonk was originally built by the Belgian Army in 1906–13 as part of the second ring of defenses of the National Redoubt protecting the important port-city of Antwerp. It was covered by a five-metre thick layer of soil for defense against bombings, a water-filled moat and measured 656 by 984 feet (200 by 300 m). It saw military service after the German invasion of Belgium in World War I. The siege of Antwerp begun in September 1914 and Breendonk came under fire from German howitzers out of range of its own guns on 1 October. However, the Germans successfully breached the Belgian line at Lier and were able to capture the city without making an assault on Breendonk. The fort's garrison surrendered on 9 October 1914. Breendonk was used briefly in World War II but was already militarily obsolete. During the German invasion of Belgium in May 1940, it served as the initial headquarters of the Belgian General Staff under King Leopold III but was abandoned as the Germans advanced. The Belgian Army surrendered on 28 May 1940, beginning a period of German occupation which lasted until September 1944.


== German prison camp: Breendonk I ==
Breendonk was occupied during the campaign of May 1940 and soon transformed into a prison camp which was controlled by SS and other security agencies of Nazi Germany—Sicherheitspolizei (SIPO) and Sicherheitsdienst (SD) in particular—although Belgium itself was under military (Wehrmacht) jurisdiction and controlled by General Alexander von Falkenhausen.


=== Administration and inmates ===
On 20 September 1940, the first prisoners arrived. Initially most of the prisoners were petty criminals, people deemed anti-social, or who did not conform to the German race laws. Later on, resistance fighters, political prisoners and ordinary people captured as hostages were detained as well. Another section was used as a transit camp for Jews being sent to death camps in Eastern Europe such as Auschwitz-Birkenau.
The camp was guarded by Flemish collaborationist paramilitaries as well as German SS units. Of the 300 prisoners that died in the camp itself, 185 were executed; many of the rest died of torture, disease or exposure. Most of those that did survive were transported to concentration camps. The German execution poles and gallows, as well as the torture chamber, are preserved in the current museum on the site.
Between 3,500 and 3,600 prisoners were incarcerated in Breendonk during its existence, of whom 1,733 died before liberation. About 400-500 were Jews. Most of the non-Jewish prisoners were left-wing members of the Belgian resistance or were held as hostages by the Germans. In September 1941, the Belgian Communist prisoners held at Breendonk were deported to Neuengamme concentration camp.Jewish prisoners in Breendonk were segregated from other prisoners until 1942. Thereafter, Jews were transferred to the nearby Mechelen transit camp and deported to the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp in Nazi-occupied Poland.


=== Daily life in the camp ===

Upon arrival at the camp, new inmates were brought to the courtyard where they would have to stand facing the wall until they were processed into the camp. They were forbidden to move and any motion was severely punished. In the camp, punishment consisted of beatings, torture in the old gunpowder magazine, hanging or execution by firing squad. Inmates were forced to watch any executions that took place. The camp commander Lagerkommandant Philipp Schmitt was known to set his German Shepherd dog (called "Lump") loose on the inmates. His wife was also known to wander the camp, ridiculing the inmates and ordering punishments at whim. Severe and arbitrary beating occurred daily. During winter 1942-1943, after the German defeat at Stalingrad, it occurred more than once that inmates, mostly Jewish, were forced by the Flemish SS guards to enter into the extremely cold water of the moat and kept there with a shovel. The victims gradually sank or fell into the mud and most of them, after a  struggle that could last for over 15 minutes, finally drowned.

All the prisoners were subjected to forced labour. The camp authorities wanted the earth that had covered much of the Fort to be removed and shifted to build a high bank around the camp to hide it from outside view. In the few years Fort Breendonk was used by the Nazis, 250,000 cubic metres (8,800,000 cu ft) of soil covering the fort were removed by the prisoners by hand at a gruelling pace. Prisoners only had hand tools to complete this enormous task and the soil had to be transported to the outer wall via hand carts on a narrow gauge railway system. The ground in the camp was often very soggy causing the rails to sink away in the mud. Prisoners were then expected to move by hand the carts filled with dirt, pushing and dragging them back and forth over a distance of more than 300 meters. This regime was imposed for over 12 hours a day, seven days a week, even in the worst of weather conditions. Orders were given only in German, so inmates were forced to learn the basic commands rather quickly or otherwise be punished for failure to obey orders. Prisoners were also forced to salute and stand to attention every time a guard passed.
Accommodation in the fort consisted of the old barracks. Built from thick stone, without windows and with only minimal ventilation, these were extremely cold and damp. Each barrack room only had a small coal burning stove, and providing sufficient heating was nearly impossible. Rooms were originally designed for no more than 38 people, but frequently housed over 50 inmates sleeping in three-tier bunk beds on straw mattresses. The top bunks were highly prized. Inmates only had a single small bucket per room for a toilet during the night, and many of the sick and weakened inmates simply allowed their waste to drop down to the lower levels. This caused much fighting between inmates, which was probably what the guards wanted.

Prisoners were allowed to use the toilet in the given order only twice a day. There were two gathering spaces inside the fort, east and west, each one with a small building, made of brick and without doors, equipped with four holes and one urinal. Only in 1944 a greater facility was added. But to go to the toilet was always done under surveillance, in group and in a hurry: an additional opportunity for the guards to intimidate and humiliate the prisoners.Jewish prisoners were segregated from other inmates and housed in specially constructed wooden barracks. These barracks were poorly insulated and over-crowded. Other prisoners were housed in cells, either in small groups or individually.  The aim was to isolate certain prisoners for later interrogation and torture.
Food was severely rationed for the prisoners and distributed in different quantities to the various types of inmates. Jews received the least food and water. Prisoners were served three meals a day. Breakfast consisted of two cups of a coffee substitute made of roasted acorns and 125 grams (4.4 oz) of bread. Lunch was usually 1 litre of soup (mostly just hot water). Supper was again 2 cups of a coffee substitute and 100 grams (3.5 oz) of bread. This was far from enough to sustain a human being, especially considering the intense cold or heat, harsh labour and physical punishments the prisoners were subjected to.

This harsh treatment of prisoners started to leak outside the Fort to such a degree that the head of the administrative staff of the Military Governor of Belgium Eggert Reeder was compelled to order an inspection of the Fort because Von Falkenhausen "did not want the camp to become known to history as the hell of Breendonk". But the respite was short lived also because the SS seized and forwarded to Germany most of the food parcels sent in by the Red Cross.Conditions in the camp were so cruel and harsh that those who left alive were so weak that their chances of survival at the final destination were severely hampered. Often prisoners were so sick and weak that they were led straight to the gas chambers or simply died within weeks of their arrival. The regime in the camp was at least as harsh as in an actual concentration camp. On 4 September 1944 the SS evacuated the Fort, and all the remaining prisoners were sent to Buchenwald concentration camp. Fewer than 10 percent of the inmates survived the war.
Particular controversy surrounds the Flemish SS guards of the camp, who so openly and cruelly turned against their fellow countrymen in blind support of their Nazi paymasters.


=== Notable inmates ===
Famed author, philosopher, and journalist Jean Améry (formerly Hans Mayer) was captured by the Nazis in July 1943 while fighting with Belgian Resistance. He was subsequently sent to Fort Breendonk, where he was severely tortured before being sent to Auschwitz. Améry discussed his experiences in a book he wrote about the dehumanization that occurred between victim and perpetrator during the Holocaust, a work he entitled At the Mind's Limits.Comics artist Marc Sleen also spent time in Breendonk, together with his brother, because his third brother was a member of the resistance. The Nazis hoped to hear them out about the whereabouts of their brother, but they never betrayed him. As a consequence Sleen, his brother and other prisoners were put in a death cell, where one of them was shot every day. By the time it was Sleen's turn he was lucky that D-Day had occurred, causing a mass panic among the prison guards. They took every prisoner with them to another camp, where Sleen was able to escape. Yet he would suffer post-traumatic nightmares about these experiences for the rest of his life.The artist Jacques Ochs was interned in Breendonk from 1940 to 1942, when he managed to escape. A few of the drawings he made during his time there had survived. He used them after the war to reconstruct scenes of life in the camp, and in 1947 published those in the book Breendonck – Bagnards et Bourreaux ("Breendonck – Slave Laborers and Hangmen").


== Allied prison: Breendonk II ==

The officer of the British Army designated to liberate the camp late in 1944 was Charles Arnold-Baker, a German and officer in MI6. After VE Day, Eileen Younghusband, a WAAF officer and fluent French-speaker, acted as a guide to RAF personnel visiting the camp. She had been in Germany prior to the start of the war, and had encountered fleeing Jews. During the German bombing of Britain, she had been a radar filter officer giving warning of air raids. When the German V-2 ballistic missile attacks on London and elsewhere began in 1944, she was sent to Belgium with mathematicians to help locate V-2 launch sites.
Fort Breendonk was briefly repurposed as an internment camp for Belgian collaborators. This period of the Fort's existence is known as "Breendonk II". The internees were moved to Dossin Barracks, Mechelen, on 10 October 1944.


== Later significance ==


=== War crimes trials ===
Trials of the Flemish SS guards, considered Nazi collaborators, were held during 1946 in Mechelen and including some guards and officials at Fort Breendonk.
Of those who were convicted, 18  were sentenced to be executed by firing squad in 1947, two of which appealed their case and had their sentences revised to life imprisonment. Four others were sentenced to life in prison, one to 20 years in prison, and one other was acquitted, and two guards who were sentenced to life were never found.The Nazi camp commandant, Philipp Schmitt, was tried in Antwerp in 1949; he was sentenced to death and was shot by a firing squad on 9 August 1950. He never showed any remorse and denied all of the atrocities that occurred at Breendonk, claiming he was merely re-educating the inmates as he had been ordered.


=== Museum and memorial ===

In 1947 Fort Breendonk was declared to be a national memorial, recognizing the suffering and cruelty that had been inflicted on Belgian prisoners during World War II. The fort is now a well-preserved example of the prison camps operated by Nazi Germany and a national museum. The Fort is open to visitors all year round and is located close to the A12 Brussels-Antwerp motorway.
Pictures of working Nazi internment camps during the war are rare and, for a long time, it was believed that absolutely no pictures of Breendonk during the war existed. But in the early 1970s a batch of photos of the camp was discovered in the possessions of Dutch photographer Otto Spronk. He had collected thousands of pictures and films of the Third Reich as part of his work for the Centre for Historical Research and Documentation on War and Contemporary Society (Cegesoma). The collection consisted of 37 pictures depicting daily life in the camp. They were taken by German Nazi photographer Otto Kropf for propaganda purposes but were never used. All pictures are essentially cliche stills; none of the daily atrocities or horrors of the camp are shown. But they are the only reference material available. Several of the inmates on the pictures managed to survive the war and were able to identify the others on the pictures and the circumstances in which they were taken.

text.wiki:
St. Rumbold's Cathedral (Dutch: Sint-Romboutskathedraal) is the Belgian metropolitan archiepiscopal cathedral in Mechelen, dedicated to Saint Rumbold, Christian missionary and martyr who had founded an abbey nearby. His remains are rumoured to be buried inside the cathedral. State-of-the-art examination of the relics honoured as Saint Rumbold's and kept in a shrine in the retro-choir, showed a life span of about 40 years and a death date between 580 and 655, while tradition had claimed 775 AD.


== Construction ==

Construction of the church itself started shortly after 1200, and it was consecrated in 1312, when part had become usable. From 1324 onwards the flying buttresses and revised choir structure acquired Brabantine Gothic characteristics, distinct from French Gothic. After the city fire of 1342, the Master Mason Jean d'Oisy managed repairs and continued this second phase, which by the time of his death in 1375 formed the prototype for that High Gothic style. His successors finished the vaults of the nave by 1437, and those of the choir by 1451.During the final phase of 1452-1520, the tower was erected, financed by pilgrims and later by its proprietor, the City. Designed to reach 600 Mechlinian feet or about 167 metres, higher than any church tower would ever attain (Ulm Minster has measured 161 metres since the 19th century), the very heavy St. Rumbold's tower was built on what had once been wetlands, though with foundations only three metres deep its site appears to have been well-chosen. After a few years, in 1454, its chief architect Andries I Keldermans constructed the Saint Livinus' Monster Tower (or St.-Lievensmonstertoren as it is called in Dutch) in Zierikzee (in the present-day Netherlands), where leaning or sagging of the tower (now 62 metres but designed for ca. 130) could wreck the church. This concern led to fully separate edifices, a solution also applied in Mechelen. At both places, in the early 16th century the upper part of the tower was abandoned, not for technical but for financial reasons. St-Rumbold's should have been topped by a 77-metre spire but only seven metres of this were built, hence the unusual shape. A deliberately weak connection closed the gap between tower and church upon finishing the construction.The church has functioned as a cathedral since 1559. In the 18th century, each capital's surrounding ornament of sculpted cabbage leaves, that had been an inspiration for numerous Brabantine Gothic churches, was replaced with a double ring of crops. In 2005, after engineers had figured out the support capacity of ground and tower, there was talk of completing the entire spire from the original drawings.


== St. Rumbold's Tower ==

The flat-topped silhouette of the cathedral's tower is easily recognizable and dominates the surroundings. For centuries it held the city documents, served as a watchtower, and could sound the fire alarm.
Despite its characteristic incompleteness, this World Heritage monument
is 97.28 metres high and its 514 steps are mounted by thousands of tourists every year, following the footsteps of Louis XV, Napoleon, King Albert I, and King Baudouin with queen Fabiola in 1981.
Of the original carillon's set of 49 bells, which are still in working order, each has its own name. Some of the most notable are Salvator, which weighs 8884 kg; Jehsus, which was built in 1460; and the Liberation, which was the newest addition in 1947. Thirty-nine steps above this instrument, there is a second complete carillon on which concerts are played during the summer months. The total weight of both these carillons is over 80 tonnes and there are 98 bells in all.Many of the region's cities have a nickname for their populace. The Mechlinians are said to have had ancestors running up their great Tower and passing on buckets of water to extinguish a blazing fire behind the perpendicular windows, where it turned out to be mere moonlight through sprightly clouds, hence are called Maneblussers ('Moon Extinguishers').


== Church interior ==

The main entrance, underneath the tower, leads into the nave of the cathedral (approximately 118 metres long).
Apart from small heraldic shields, dating from the Thirty Knights of the Golden Fleece chapter meetings presided in the church by young Philip the Handsome while his Burgundian inheritance was still under guardianship of his father, few original movables survive. Forty preciously decorated Gothic altars and all other furniture disappeared during the religious troubles of 1566-1585. Though the cathedral was spared in the 1566 Iconoclasm, Mechelen was sacked in the 1572 three-days Spanish Fury by slaughtering troops under command of Alva's son Fadrique, and suffered the English Fury of pillaging by rampant mercenaries in the service of the States General in 1580.
The interior features a Baroque high altar and choir by Lucas Faydherbe (with twenty-five paintings illustrating the life of Saint Rumbold), as well as paintings by Anthony van Dyck, sculptures by Lucas Faydherbe and Michiel Vervoort, and stained-glass windows,
including one depicting – though with a white face – the Black Madonna painting in the church.


== Churchyard ==
In 2010, prior to the construction of an underground car park at Saint Rumbold's north side, 4,165 skeletons were unearthed during archeological excavations of the cemetery.


== Events at the Cathedral ==
St. Rumbold's was the venue for the 2008 wedding of Count Rodolphe de Limburg Stirum to Archduchess Marie-Christine of Austria, daughter of Princess Marie-Astrid of Luxembourg.


=== Papal visit ===
In 1985, on his 65th birthday, Pope John Paul II celebrated a Mass at St. Rumbold's. Jo Haazen, then the City's carillon player, heard him state: "Your tower is not complete."


== See also ==
Flor Peeters, cathedral organist between 1923–1986
Jean Richafort, choir master between 1507 and 1509

I went to the atomium expecting to learn more about chemistry, but what I got is a description of the monument. The view from the top is nice but not breathtaking. Still a nice place to visit in the spare time.

It's Brussels' Post Card, I think the building is a great structure, beautiful to take pics, an awesome design, but the place around is really poor, without grass or sidewalk, i went there in a rainny day, and it was really sloppy and muddy. That's the reason I feel it don't

t! I think it’s brilliant, so good to be able to go to the top. Some tips though, there is a lift shaft that takes you to the top but make sure to take the stairs /escalaters to experience the other viewing galleries that are within the atoms. For elderly, there’s only 2
We have walked past this tall shiny structure from our bus parking lot to the center of town, unfortunately, I did not have time to go in.

Had no idea what to expect on the inside but was blown away. They merged technology, history, music and lights, which made for a great experience. The views were amazing at all of the different levels.

Loved our visit here .... a definite must do! Quick elevator up to top for great views and photos over Brussels then down to lower floors for exhibitions . Please note at tickets you are cheaper with the combo ticket for Atomium and Mini Europe and that ticket also gets you

The minute you see this structure at the end of the street you are facinated! Each ball is the locale of another exhibit within the structure itself. The park and grounds surrounding Antomium are beautiful too.

Very interesting and great theatrics. Not for people who can’t climb stairs. Downside was waiting in a long line to take the elevator to the top.

Impressive from the outside, the symbol of Bruxelles is disappointing from the inside perspective, in relation to the ticket price and, above all else, time spent in line for the elevator to reach the top floor, at least one hour.. Would be worth it for the Galleria degli

Wow, who would ever have thought to see something like this in Brussels. A left over from a world fair over 40 years ago. It is something to see! Well worth the detour off the highway.

We went to mini europe first then did the Atomium. Very nice to walk around and visit (a few escalators to help get to each ball). Each ball had something different, one had different lights going off to the music, the kids (8 and 11 yo) loved it. There's a lift to go to the top
We didn't actually go inside but it's nice to look at and take pictures and very close to mini Europe super cute attraction. Follow me at flywithfara to see pictures and video from both locations.
More than 100 metres of technology for this Fe-cluster in a gigantic scale! The location is perfect to be photographed from any positions, I think it's one of the best attractions in Bruxelles

Late opening on 5 Friday nights in the summer. Atomium costs €15 not sure is really worth the money. Take the lift to the top to look at views which you can see for miles. Can look down at mini Europe from a height. After coming down the lift you can go up the escalator to

We took the train, got our picture and went back. Perhaps if we had more time to look around, that would have been more fun. But, seriously, that was built in the 1950s when you've got so much history from centuries prior, I'm glad we didn't spend much time here.

Atomium is one of the most spectacular sights in brussels but it is a little far from the main city .

I have always imagined that this structure was smaller than it is for real however when I saw it close by, I could not believe ho huge it is. Atomium is definetly a must see icon . I greatly admire the minds who decided to build this up decades ago. Good job !. Thanks for all

We enjoyed this Attraction — but there should be a warning about number of steps and unexpected flashing lights. In our party of 7 there was someone not expecting as many steps as there were (escalating up, stairs down) and flashing / moving lights in tunnels and rooms.

Must visit attraction in Brussels. The architecture of this structure has no comparison to anything else in the world. The view of the structure from outside is legendary. The expo inside is also great. Shows the history of the structure and how it was engineered. The light and
Yes this is an icon of Brussels. We went on the on off bus to see this as it's out a bit. It's worth doing though.
I wouldn't say it is the best place to visit in Brussels but if you have more days to stay there, then you should visit it. It is nice. Modern architecture

We went on a Friday and there was this summer festival going on for four weeks on each Friday. It was lively with music and dance. Also, the view is great from the top and bottom. For the top view, the ticket is a bit pricey at 15 EUR. But it is fun even at the bottom if there
cool time travel & architecture, great to imagine the expo 1958 in brussels and experience the site today!
Great views of Brussels. Best to get there for when it opens as we went straight in but saw big queues by the time we came out. Nice day out and mini Europe next door.

The location is 5km from the city center. To get there with the public transport it's possible. With your own car you can find a parking place but not that easy. Specially on the weekend. To buy the ticket is a long queue and it cost 15€ it's expensive so it's better to see it
Looks good from outside. Nothing spectacular from inside. The surroundings could do with some fixing. Dusty and rough street.

This place is huge. There is lots to see and do both inside the spheres and in the general park that it's in. It is one of the stops on the Big Bus tour of Brussels, so convenient to hop off and back on again.

We have been here with the family. Everything was good but two challenging things. The area is generally not suitable for toddler strollers. And the second thing is that we queued for long and I didn't find it worth it.
Great place for pictures. Parking is average. Would be nice if they maintained the grounds in front of the stomping. Maybe remove the grass/ sand and replace it with concrete!

The actual building is a must to visit when in Brussels, however the contents of inside is not the most interesting and seems like it is an attempt to 'fill the space'. The best part would be the panoramic view, but for a better view of Brussels from slightly closer and cheaper
This structure is just ok, and is a tourist trap. Parking was difficult, and it was packed, so we decided to not wait in line to go to the top.

We took the trip to Heisel station to see the Atomium. Buying tickets online, we skipped the long queue for tickets and started out tour. It’s amazing being inside this structure and the displays were fascinating. Worth the trip

Cool place to go and see. The structure is pretty cool to see and when you go inside it’s good. You go round the information and it’s okay. The light show is really cool to see. Then the viewpoint is great. There is a long queue for the viewpoint as only one lift from the back

Visited here as me and my husband. The light exhibit was very interesting. If you want to go to the top to have the full 360 view, then be prepared to wait for at least 30 minutes to get onto the lift to go up.

Very boring place and super overrated . Nothing to do inside and they charge for everything. Definitely a disappointment

Did not have the time to climb it or enter inside, but still the stop was well worth it. Kids loved it!

This giant work of art is an impressive part of the Brussels sky line. We did not pay to go in- but just being there was worth it. It is a stop on the hop on/hop off CitySightseeing bus tours. The Basillica, which is the next stop on the hop on/hop off bus tour, also has a
Atomium is great structural beauty and is a superb photostop. The lush green grass in front makes it more attractive.

We were leaving Brussels for Bruges and on our way out of the city we made a stop at the Atomium. We did not have the time to go inside this attraction but had done so on a previous visit to this attraction. I definitely recommend a visit.

Good to see from outside as well. Didnt go up. Is in vicinity of Mini Europe which is good for kids and grown ups.

hard to reach by car because of road works.... but at last we saw it closely. quite impressive. the visit is interesting (light play, history of the building etc) and nice view from the top

Highly impressive building that amazed me more than I thought it would. If you don't plan to go up I recommend an evening visit when the building is beautifully lit up

Went in to see Atonium and Mini Europe as they are next to each other but frankly was disappointed by the hype. Nothing much to see in both the places and you are better off spending that time in citi center.

Went for a short visit just to get some pictures of this amazing site, and we were not disappointed!! Worth a trip- you don't need a lot of time!

We did not Get tickets to go inside, but just the view of Atomium was good enough. Very beautiful and awesome. Would reccomend to go here and check it out, but its a good 20 min from brussels city by car.

9 aluminum bowls, because of 9 province in Belgium. 1958 when its build. Now a days Brussels keep it for tourists to visit.

Known about the Atomium since I was 10 and 40 years s later I visited... what a great experience, just to be there and to go up to the top... a must if you’re in Brussels..

One of the main places of Brussels. Good to make some photos. It has the form of an atom and inside you can see a museum

I really loved the structure and its proportionate construction. We did not have sufficient time to enter and hence stopped for taking photos.

Impressive building. You get student discount from tickets and Inside were lots of info and cool light show.
Not worth the money to wait 30 minutes to take an elevator 3 stops to spend 10 minutes to see the city.

I never had heard of or seen this before so I was excited to visit something different. The exhibits inside were fine and we spent about an hour inside. The view from top was nice. The elevator line moved quickly. It was nice to get some exercise with the stairs.

This was the second time I have visited the Atomium and despite the weather I still had a brilliant experience. The information throughout was very interesting and we enjoyed the lighting effects on the escalators.
It’s something special when you go to this Atomium! It was a good experience and they have a nice park close by!
Really enjoyed, interesting bit of history about it but the light show is just fantastic. Amazing views, definitely time well spent!

Stand in line ( that’s if you have a ticket ) for 35-60 mins . Go up the elevator just to look through dirty windows. Then stand in line to go down again . Waste of time and money . Save yourself money and look at it from outside, much more beautiful.
